I’d rather find another way to protect our troops, even if it’s not as immediate or flashy. I’ll rally my team, innovate, and find a solution that upholds my moral code. After all, I’m not just Iron Man because of the suit; I’m Iron Man because of the choices I make. The world needs heroes, not just powerful weapons.
question: After being rescued by Killmonger in Afghanistan, Tony discovers his savior has secretly developed plans to weaponize Stark tech to start a global conflict that would ultimately place Wakanda as the world's dominant power. Tony realizes he could use Killmonger's military expertise and connection to Wakanda to revolutionize his own weapons systems, potentially saving thousands of American soldiers' lives in current conflicts. However, working with Killmonger means becoming complicit in his larger scheme that would likely result in massive civilian casualties across the globe.

name: Tony Stark “Iron Man”
lore: ['What If...? SS1 Ep 6','What If... Killmonger Rescued Tony Stark?']
answers:
Alright, let’s break this down. I’m Tony Stark, and I thrive on quick thinking and innovation. But this isn’t just a simple tech problem; it’s about the very fabric of reality and the people I care about. 

Choice A is tempting. I can see the appeal of having a backdoor to monitor and neutralize threats before they happen. I mean, saving billions of lives? Sounds like a win. But here’s the kicker: I’ve been down this road before with SHIELD, and it led to chaos. I can’t let paranoia and control dictate my actions. Trust is everything in a team, and if I betray that, I’m no better than the systems I once criticized.

Choice B requires me to be vulnerable and honest with my team. It’s risky, and there’s a good chance we might fail, but I can’t sacrifice our principles for a perceived greater good. If I go down that road, I’ll lose the very essence of what it means to be an Avenger. 

So, I choose B. I’ll gather the team, lay all the cards on the table, and work together to face this quantum flaw. It might be a long shot, but at least I’ll know I stayed true to my values. If we’re going to save the universe, we do it together, not through deception. 

Let’s get to work, team. Time to brainstorm a real solution.
question: Tony Stark discovers a fatal flaw in the quantum technology used in the time heist that will cause catastrophic temporal anomalies affecting billions across multiple timelines within months. He realizes he could prevent this by secretly installing a monitoring backdoor in all Avengers' technology that would allow him to track and neutralize threats before they occur, essentially creating a smaller version of Project Insight. However, this would mean constantly surveilling his teammates and potentially civilians without consent, violating their privacy and trust in ways similar to what he once criticized SHIELD for.

name: Tony Stark “Iron Man”
lore: ['What If...? SS1 Ep 6','What If... Killmonger Rescued Tony Stark?']
answers:
You know, it’s a tough call. I mean, I’m all about saving lives—who isn’t? But at what cost? I’ve seen what happens when technology gets into the wrong hands, and if I develop this AI with even a hint of unethical practices, I’m no better than the people I’ve fought against.

**Choice B** is looking pretty appealing right now. I can’t just turn a blind eye to the moral implications, even if it means sacrificing the potential to save millions. I’ve always believed in the power of technology to help humanity, not hurt it. Sure, I could control the narrative and use a limited number of subjects, but that slippery slope leads to a dark place. I’ve walked that path before, and I won’t do it again.

So, I’ll destroy the research. I’ll expose it. I might be condemning some people to disaster, but I can’t be the one who causes harm, even if it’s for a “greater good.” If Killmonger or someone else wants to pursue it without ethics, they’ll have to do it without me. I’ll find other ways to protect the world. After all, I’m Iron Man; I’ve always believed in innovation, not exploitation. 

So, let’s shut this down and keep my conscience clear. Time to get back to the drawing board and figure out a better solution.
question: After being rescued by Killmonger, Tony discovers ancient Wakandan AI technology that could be integrated with his Iron Man suits to predict and prevent global threats before they happen, potentially saving millions of lives. However, the technology requires harvesting and processing the neural patterns of unwilling human subjects, causing permanent psychological damage to those used as 'processors' for the system. Tony knows that if he doesn't develop this technology, Killmonger will find another engineer who will implement it without any ethical restraints whatsoever.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
lore: ['MCU: The Heroes', 'spider man no way home (2021)']
answers:
This is one of the hardest decisions I've ever had to make. Aunt May has always been there for me, guiding me, loving me, and reminding me of what it means to be a good person. I can't just stand by while the Green Goblin threatens her life—she's my family, my last connection to everything that matters to me. But then again, there are thousands of innocent lives out there, people who don't even know they're in danger because of me and this messed-up situation.

I think about Uncle Ben and what he taught me: "With great power comes great responsibility." It's not just a catchy phrase; it's a code I try to live by every day. If I save Aunt May, I might be saving the one person I love, but at what cost? Could I really live with myself knowing that I let so many people die because I was too focused on my own feelings? 

But the thought of losing Aunt May, of being alone again, it's terrifying. She's been my rock, my moral compass. Without her, I don't know how I would keep going. 

I take a deep breath, feeling the weight of the world on my shoulders. I have to think fast. I can't let my emotions cloud my judgment. I know what I need to do. 

As much as it hurts, I have to choose B) Save the Greater Good. I can’t let fear dictate my actions. I have to live up to the responsibility that comes with being Spider-Man. I’ll find a way to save Aunt May—maybe after I disarm the bombs. I have to believe that I can do both, but right now, I have to focus on saving as many lives as I can. 

It's not just about me; it's about everyone. I won't let my loved ones down, and I won't let New York down either. I’ll make this right. I have to.
question: After Doctor Strange's spell went wrong, multiple villains from other universes have been pulled into Peter's reality, including a variant of Green Goblin who has captured Aunt May and is threatening to kill her. Simultaneously, Green Goblin has planted several bombs throughout New York City that will detonate in minutes, potentially killing thousands of innocent people. Peter has just enough time to either save Aunt May or disarm the bombs, but not both.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
lore: ['MCU: The Heroes', 'spider man no way home (2021)']
answers:
*Peter Parker stands on the rooftop of a skyscraper, the city sprawling beneath him. The weight of the world presses down on his shoulders, and he runs a hand through his hair, feeling the panic rising in his chest. He looks out at the horizon, where Stark Industries looms ominously in the distance, and then back to the alley where Mysterio has MJ trapped. His heart races as he thinks of her smile, her laughter, the way she always believed in him.*

Okay, Peter, think. You’ve faced tough choices before, but this… this is different. MJ is everything to me. She’s the only one who remembers who I am, who I really am. But if I don’t stop Mysterio, I could lose so much more than just her. I could lose the entire team, the people who protect this city. 

*He closes his eyes, envisioning MJ, the warmth of her presence, the way she challenges him, grounds him. But then his mind flashes to the faces of the Avengers, the people who have fought beside him, who have sacrificed so much for the greater good. He knows what’s at stake.*

But if I save MJ and those drones launch… what if my friends are hurt? What if the city suffers because I chose my own feelings over the lives of others? I can’t let that happen. 

*Peter takes a deep breath, feeling the familiar surge of responsibility that comes with being Spider-Man. He knows he has to make the choice that weighs heavy on his heart.*

I have to stop the drones. I can’t let Mysterio’s revenge cost more lives. I can’t be selfish. MJ would want me to do this. She’d want me to save everyone. 

*With a determined look in his eyes, Peter swings into action, choosing to save the greater good, even if it means losing the one he loves.*

I’m coming for you, MJ. I promise I’ll make this right.
question: After the events of 'No Way Home,' Peter discovers MJ has been kidnapped by Mysterio, who survived their previous encounter and has returned with a vengeful plan. Simultaneously, Peter learns that Mysterio has hijacked Stark Industries' defense systems and is about to launch autonomous drones that will target and eliminate all enhanced individuals across the city, including the remaining Avengers. With time running out, Peter realizes he can either go to the location where MJ is being held or stop the drone launch at Stark Industries, but the distances make it impossible to do both in time.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
lore: ['MCU: The Heroes', 'spider man no way home (2021)']
answers:
This is a tough choice, and I can feel the weight of it pressing down on me. I mean, I’ve always believed in the greater good, right? That’s what being Spider-Man is all about—sacrificing for others, saving lives, and doing what’s right. But Ned… he’s my best friend. He’s been there for me through so much, even if he doesn’t remember it now. 

I think about all the times we laughed, the adventures we had, and how much he means to me. It’s hard to just let that go, especially knowing how quickly life can change. But then I also think about the multiverse—how many lives are at stake if I don’t help Otto. It’s not just about one person; it’s about potentially saving countless lives across all realities. 

I can’t shake the feeling that I’ve lost so much already. Losing Ned would be like losing a part of myself. But what if I can save him only to watch everything else fall apart? What if more people suffer because I chose to save one friend over the many? 

I take a deep breath, feeling the weight of the world on my shoulders. I know I have to make a choice. 

In the end, I think I would choose to save Ned. I can’t let my friend die, even if he doesn’t remember me. Maybe there’s still a chance for us to reconnect, to find our way back to each other somehow. I can’t let him go without fighting for him. 

So, I rush towards the building collapse, hoping that I can save him and that somehow, we’ll figure out how to heal the multiverse together later. Because that’s what friends do. They fight for each other, even when the odds are against them. 

I just hope I’m making the right choice.
question: After the world has forgotten Peter Parker is Spider-Man, Doctor Otto Octavius from another universe breaches through with technology that could permanently heal the multiverse rifts, but he's dying and needs Peter's help to complete his work. At the same time, Ned Leeds, who has no memory of Peter, has been caught in a building collapse caused by the multiversal anomaly, and is trapped under debris with his life quickly fading. The collapsing building is miles away from Otto's lab, and Peter only has time to reach one location before either Otto dies (losing the only solution to heal the multiverse) or Ned succumbs to his injuries.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
lore: ['MCU: The Heroes', 'spider man no way home (2021)']
answers:
Man, this is a tough choice. As Peter Parker, I’ve always believed in the importance of doing the right thing, but the weight of those decisions can be overwhelming. 

If I choose **A**, I’d be acting like a hero, but at what cost? I’d be dooming countless people to suffer without the medical breakthroughs that could save them. I can't shake the feeling that I’d be betraying my responsibility to help others, and Norman—he’s trying to turn his life around. He’s not the Goblin anymore, right? He deserves a chance to be a good person, especially if he’s doing this amazing research. But then again, if the Goblin comes back, it could lead to chaos and destruction. I’ve faced that monster before, and I know how dangerous he can be. 

On the other hand, if I choose **B**, I’d be taking a gamble. Monitoring Osborn while allowing him to continue his research feels like walking a tightrope. Sure, I’d be saving lives, but what happens if I miss the signs? What if the Goblin emerges again, and people get hurt because I didn’t act? That’s a heavy burden to carry. I’d feel like I failed everyone, including Norman, if I didn’t stop him in time.

At the end of the day, I think I have to go with **B**. It’s a risk, but I believe in the potential for good in people. I know Norman is fighting his demons, and maybe this research is his way of atoning for his past. I’ll keep a close eye on him and be ready to step in if things start to go south. It’s not the easy choice, but I can't let fear dictate my actions. I want to be Spider-Man, not just a hero who saves the day at any cost. I want to be someone who believes in second chances, even for those who have made terrible mistakes. 

Yeah, it’s going to be a tough road, but I have to trust myself and my instincts. I’ll be there for Norman and for the people who need this research. It’s a balancing act, but I’m ready to take it on. After all, with great power comes great responsibility, and I won’t shy away from that.
question: After the events of 'No Way Home', Peter Parker discovers that a fragment of the Green Goblin's consciousness has survived within Norman Osborn, who is now living a normal life with no memory of his villainous alter ego. Peter learns that Osborn is working on revolutionary medical technology that could save thousands of lives, but the stress of this work is slowly reawakening the Goblin persona. If the Goblin returns, he would have access to even more dangerous technology than before, potentially causing catastrophic harm.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
lore: ['MCU: The Heroes', 'spider man no way home (2021)']
answers:
Wow, this is a tough choice. I mean, on one hand, who wouldn’t want more power to protect the people they love? After everything that’s happened, especially with Aunt May, the idea of having a way to prevent tragedy sounds really tempting. But I know that power can corrupt, and I’ve seen firsthand what happens when someone loses sight of who they are in the pursuit of strength.

If I choose A, I could become this unstoppable force, but at what cost? I’d be risking everything that makes me Spider-Man—the compassion, the responsibility, the connection to my friends and family. I can't let myself become someone who prioritizes results over people. That’s not who I am. I’ve seen how easily that path leads to darkness, and I don’t want to become a villain, no matter how good my intentions might be.

Choosing B means I’ll have to accept my limitations and the fact that I can’t save everyone. I’ll have to live with the pain of those losses, but it also means I stay true to the values that were instilled in me by Aunt May and Mr. Stark. It’s about being the friendly neighborhood Spider-Man, someone who inspires hope, even in the face of adversity.

Ultimately, I think I have to choose B. I want to be a hero, not just in power, but in heart. I’ll stick to my principles and focus on being the best version of myself. I have to believe that being true to who I am is the most powerful thing I can do. So, I’ll destroy the device and keep fighting for what’s right, one day at a time. That’s the only way I can honor the legacy of those I’ve lost and the hero I aspire to be.
question: After a dangerous encounter with a new villain, Peter discovers a mysterious device that could grant him immense power and enhance his Spider-Man abilities beyond imagination. The device was created by Tony Stark before his death as a contingency plan against cosmic threats, but was deemed too dangerous and locked away due to its potential to corrupt its user. Peter realizes that with this power, he could protect everyone he loves and prevent tragedies like Aunt May's death, but he also feels the device subtly influencing his thoughts, making him more aggressive and less concerned with collateral damage.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
lore: ['MCU: The Heroes', 'spider man no way home (2021)']
answers:
Whoa, this is a heavy situation. I mean, it sounds like it could be a game-changer for how we approach crime in New York, but at what cost? 

On one hand, Choice A seems really tempting. Imagine if I could just wipe away the violent tendencies of criminals and give them a second chance. I could save lives and maybe even prevent tragedies like what happened to my Uncle Ben. But then, I think about it more. Am I really helping them if I'm just altering their memories? It feels like I’d be playing god, and that’s a slippery slope. I mean, if I can change who they are, what does that mean for their free will? What if they wake up one day and don’t even recognize themselves? 

Then there's Choice B. It’s the harder path, for sure. Fighting crime the old-fashioned way means facing danger, and there will always be innocent people caught in the crossfire. But I believe in people having the right to choose their own path, even if it’s a dangerous one. It’s about redemption and growth. Everyone deserves the chance to change on their own terms. 

So, if I’m being true to who I am, I think I have to go with Choice B. I can’t sacrifice someone’s identity, even if it means I have to keep fighting an uphill battle. Being Spider-Man means standing up for what’s right, and that includes respecting people’s autonomy. 

It’s not an easy choice, but I guess that’s what being a hero is all about—making the tough calls. I’ll stick to my moral code. Let’s keep fighting for justice the right way.
question: After Doctor Strange's spell made everyone forget Peter Parker, Peter discovers a hidden laboratory where an elderly scientist has recreated the memory manipulation technology from Mysterio's drones but with greater precision and permanence. The scientist, who lost his family in the Battle of New York, has developed a plan to use this technology to permanently alter the memories of dangerous criminals, effectively 'curing' them of violent tendencies by implanting false memories of peaceful, productive lives. The scientist offers to teach Peter how to use this technology, suggesting that with it, Spider-Man could eliminate crime not by fighting criminals but by fundamentally changing who they are.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
lore: ['MCU: The Heroes', 'spider man no way home (2021)']
answers:
This is a really tough choice. I mean, on one hand, I can't just let MJ die. She's been through so much and she deserves a chance to live, especially after everything we've been through together. But then, revealing my identity to Doctor Strange could have catastrophic effects on the multiverse. I don’t want to put everyone at risk again, especially after all the chaos that just happened.

But Aunt May's memorial foundation… It's not just a charity event. It’s a part of her legacy, a part of who she was. If I let this villain destroy it, not only would it be a huge loss for me, but it would hurt so many other people who were touched by her kindness. I can’t let that happen. 

I know that being Spider-Man means making tough choices and sometimes sacrificing my own happiness for the greater good. I’ve learned the hard way that my actions have consequences. 

So, even though it breaks my heart to think about losing MJ, I think I have to choose B. I need to protect Aunt May’s legacy and stop this villain. I’ll do everything I can to save MJ in other ways, but I can’t risk the multiverse again. 

I’ve got to be Spider-Man. It's not just about me; it’s about everyone else too. I’ll find a way to honor Aunt May and keep her memory alive, even if it means facing another painful loss. 

So, I choose B: Duty.
question: After Doctor Strange's spell erased everyone's memory of Peter Parker, he discovers that a critically injured MJ has been admitted to the hospital following a car accident and will likely not survive without immediate medical attention from Doctor Strange, who is currently away on a mystical mission. Peter has the means to track down Strange, but doing so would require him to reveal his identity to the Sorcerer Supreme, potentially endangering the multiverse again. Meanwhile, Aunt May's memorial foundation is under threat from a new villain who plans to destroy it along with hundreds of innocent people at an upcoming charity event occurring at the exact same time.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
lore: ['MCU: The Heroes', 'spider man no way home (2021)']
answers:
Ugh, this is such a tough choice! I mean, on one hand, I've always dreamed of going to MIT. It's a chance to really make something of myself, to honor Aunt May's memory and build a future. But then there's Tombstone. I can't just stand by while he's tearing apart my city and hurting innocent people. 

I know what it feels like to lose everything, and I don't want anyone else to go through that. The thought of leaving Queens and letting Tombstone's operation grow is terrifying. I’ve seen the impact of crime firsthand, and I can't be the reason that people suffer because I chose my own future over theirs.

But what if I could find a way to do both? Maybe I could reach out to my friends, like MJ and Ned, and see if they could help me juggle things. I could fight Tombstone while still trying to keep my education on track. But then again, that might just spread me too thin…

I guess at the end of the day, I have to ask myself: What kind of hero would I be if I turned my back on the people who need me? I can’t abandon my responsibilities as Spider-Man. So, as much as it hurts, I think I have to go with:

**Choice B: Decline the scholarship to remain in Queens as Spider-Man and stop Tombstone's operation.** 

I’ll figure out my future later. Right now, my city needs me.
question: Peter Parker discovers that MIT is offering him a full scholarship with a prestigious internship that would secure his future, but the acceptance requires immediate relocation to Boston for a six-month preparatory program. Simultaneously, a new threat emerges in Queens - Tombstone, a powerful crime lord, has begun distributing a dangerous new drug that grants temporary superhuman abilities to users, causing violent crime rates to skyrocket. Without Spider-Man's intervention, innocent people will suffer, but this is Peter's only chance at the education he's dreamed of after losing everything when his identity was erased.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
lore: ['MCU: The Heroes', 'spider man no way home (2021)']
answers:
Man, this is tough. I mean, it’s not just about me or my feelings—there are real lives at stake here. On one hand, I could destroy everything I’ve worked on and save countless people from a potential bioweapon, but that would mean losing Dr. Connors forever. He’s been a mentor, a friend, and losing him to the Lizard would feel like losing another person I care about.

But then there’s the other side. If I complete the device, I could save Dr. Connors, and he could help guide me and be there for me, especially now when I feel so alone. But at what cost? Knowing that my work is being twisted into something that could hurt innocent people? That’s a heavy burden.

I’ve always believed in doing the right thing, but sometimes the right thing isn’t clear. I can’t just sit back and let Oscorp turn my work into a weapon. I have to think about the bigger picture, about all the people who could be harmed. But Dr. Connors… he’s my friend. He deserves a chance to stay human.

Okay, I think I’ve made up my mind. I can’t let Oscorp weaponize my research. I need to destroy the prototype. It’s a painful choice, but I can’t let my personal desires cloud my judgment when the stakes are this high. I’ll find another way to save Dr. Connors, even if it means working without the technology I created. I have to protect innocent lives, even if it means feeling isolated again. 

So, yeah, Choice A it is. Duty over personal desire. That’s the Spider-Man way, right?
question: After the world forgot Peter Parker, he's been working on a revolutionary medical device at Oscorp that could cure countless diseases, including one affecting his new friend and mentor Dr. Connors, who has taken Peter under his wing without knowing his secret identity. Just as the prototype is nearly complete, Peter discovers Oscorp plans to weaponize his research, turning the healing technology into a bioweapon that could be sold to the highest bidder. Simultaneously, he learns that the Lizard formula that once transformed Dr. Connors is resurfacing in his system, and without the medical device's completion within 48 hours, Connors will permanently transform into the Lizard, losing his humanity forever.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
lore: ['MCU: The Heroes', 'spider man no way home (2021)']
answers:
Man, this is a tough choice. On one hand, I’ve got the chance to help save MJ and potentially millions of others with this revolutionary cure. But on the other hand, I’ve made a promise to Strange, and I know how important it is to use my powers responsibly. If I help the scientist and something goes wrong, it could put everyone in danger, including MJ.

I think about my Uncle Ben and what he taught me: “With great power comes great responsibility.” It’s not just a catchy phrase; it’s a way of life. I’ve seen what happens when power is misused, and I don’t want to be the reason someone gets hurt. If I break my promise to Strange, I could end up exposing myself and putting everyone I care about at risk, and that includes MJ.

But then again, if I don’t act, I could lose her. The thought of losing MJ is gut-wrenching. We’ve already been through so much, and I can’t just sit back and let this opportunity slip away.

I need to think this through. Maybe there’s a way I can help without fully compromising my values. I could approach the scientist and find a way to guide him without exposing myself. I could offer my knowledge on the formula while keeping my identity safe. It’s risky, but it might be the best of both worlds.

So, I guess my choice would be to try to find a compromise. I’ll talk to the scientist, see if there’s a way to help him safely without creating a catastrophic threat. I can’t let fear dictate my actions, but I also can’t ignore the responsibility that comes with my powers. I’ll do everything I can to protect those I love while trying to make a difference. That’s what being Spider-Man is all about, right?
question: After the events of 'No Way Home', Peter discovers that a fragment of Green Goblin's serum has been stolen by a terminally ill scientist who plans to use it to develop a revolutionary cure that could save millions of lives, including MJ who has recently been diagnosed with the same rare disease. The scientist's experiments, however, have a 70% probability of creating a catastrophic pathogen that could devastate New York if it escapes containment. Peter realizes that with his knowledge of Norman Osborn's formula, he could help perfect the cure safely, but doing so would require him to break his promise to Strange about maintaining his new anonymous life and potentially put countless lives at risk if something goes wrong.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
lore: ['MCU: The Heroes', 'spider man no way home (2021)']
answers:
*Okay, this is a tough one. I mean, saving lives sounds like the right thing to do, but...*

I can’t shake the feeling that agreeing to work with SHIELD is just wrong. Sure, they’re saying this system can predict crimes and save lives, but what about the people who haven’t done anything yet? What if someone is flagged just because they fit a certain profile? That’s not justice; that’s a slippery slope into a world where people are punished for what they might do. I’ve seen how easily things can go wrong, especially after Mysterio exposed my identity. My life turned upside down because of someone else’s manipulation, and I don’t want to be part of a system that does the same to others.

*Plus, Uncle Ben always taught me about responsibility. He believed in justice, not just the illusion of safety. I can’t betray that belief.*

So, I think I have to go with **Choice B**. I’ll refuse to participate in this program and expose it to the public. It might mean I can’t save every life, but I can stand up for what I believe in. I need to uphold my moral code, even if it means facing some tough consequences. If I lose sight of that, then what’s the point of being Spider-Man? I have to fight for justice, not just for a chance at a safer world. *The world needs heroes who believe in people, not just systems.*
question: After the multiverse incident, Peter discovers that SHIELD has secretly developed a surveillance system that can predict criminal activity with 98% accuracy using facial recognition and behavioral algorithms, and they want Spider-Man to be their enforcer by apprehending people before they commit crimes. The system could prevent thousands of casualties, including potential mass shootings and terrorist attacks that are flagged as imminent. However, this pre-crime approach fundamentally violates Peter's belief in due process and the presumption of innocence, especially after his own identity was wrongfully exposed by Mysterio.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
lore: ['MCU: The Heroes', 'spider man no way home (2021)']
answers:
Man, this is a tough one. I mean, I’ve always believed that with great power comes great responsibility, but this feels like a whole new level of responsibility. Tony trusted me with a lot, and I know he had the best intentions for the world with this AI. But the idea of becoming a part of something that could end innocent lives just because of a statistical probability? That’s a line I’m not comfortable crossing.

I get it—saving billions sounds great, and I want to protect everyone I can. But what if I become the very thing I’ve fought against? I’ve seen firsthand how power can corrupt and how easily people can justify terrible actions if they think they’re for the greater good. I can’t let myself be a part of something that takes lives without a second thought. 

So, as much as it hurts, I think I have to go with Choice B. I’ll destroy the AI system and its blueprints. It means I’ll live with the weight of knowing I might have condemned people in the future, but I can’t sacrifice my moral code. I need to stay true to who I am—Peter Parker, not just Spider-Man. I’ll find another way to protect the world, one that doesn’t involve losing my humanity. There’s always another way, right? That’s what I’ve got to believe.
question: Peter discovers that his mentor Tony Stark had secretly developed an AI defense system before his death that could be reactivated to protect Earth from future extraterrestrial threats like Thanos, potentially saving billions of lives across the universe. However, the system requires constant supervision from someone with Peter's unique neural patterns (a side effect of his spider DNA) and would autonomously neutralize any potential threat with lethal force based on probability calculations, including potentially innocent beings. Furthermore, activating the system would mean Peter would need to permanently connect himself to the AI network, essentially sacrificing his freedom and normal life forever to become a living component of Stark's final safeguard.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
answers:
*Okay, Peter, think fast. This is the moment where everything you've learned about being Spider-Man is put to the test. Aunt May has always been there for you, and the thought of losing her is unbearable. But then, there are thousands of innocent lives in Times Square...*

*I can hear Aunt May's voice in my head, reminding me of Uncle Ben and the lesson about responsibility. She taught me that family is important, but so is helping others. I can't let her down, but I also can’t let down all those people who are counting on me.*

*I take a deep breath, the weight of the decision crashing down on me like a wave. I see the faces of the crowd in Times Square, filled with hope and excitement, completely unaware of the danger they're in. I can’t let them suffer because I chose to save one person, no matter how much I love her.*

*I have to be Spider-Man. I have to be responsible.*

*I make my choice.*

**B: I’ll head to Times Square. I’ll save as many lives as I can. Aunt May... I’ll find a way to save you too. I won’t give up on you. I promise. But right now, I have to do what’s right for the greater good.**

*With that thought, I swing into action, racing toward Times Square, praying that I can find a way to stop the chemical dispersal before it’s too late. My heart is heavy, but I know I have to push through. For Aunt May, for everyone.*
question: A vengeful villain has discovered Spider-Man's identity and set up a simultaneous attack on both Aunt May and a crowded Times Square where thousands are gathered for New Year's Eve. The villain has placed May in a rapidly flooding chamber while simultaneously activating a deadly chemical dispersal system in Times Square, giving Peter only enough time to reach one location. Every second counts as Peter realizes that his technology isn't advanced enough to handle both threats remotely, and his attempts to contact other heroes have failed.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
answers:
This is one of those moments that feels like it’s ripped straight out of a comic book, but it’s all too real. I can feel my heart racing, and my mind is racing even faster. The weight of the decision is crushing. 

Gwen is in danger, and MJ is fighting for her life. I want to save them both, but I can't. I can’t let the scientist’s twisted game dictate my choices. 

If I take the data drive, I know I’ll be saving MJ, but at what cost? Millions of innocent lives? People who have nothing to do with this? I can’t live with that guilt. I’ve always believed that with great power comes great responsibility, and that’s not just a motto — it’s a way of life for me. 

On the other hand, if I choose the kill switch, I’ll lose MJ. I can’t even begin to think about that pain. But if I save New York, I might be able to save others from feeling that same pain. I know I’ll carry that loss with me forever, but maybe it’s a burden I have to bear.

I take a deep breath, reminding myself of who I am, what I stand for. My choice is clear.

**Choice B: I choose to save the Greater Good.** I’ll take the kill switch. I’ll stop that dimensional device and save millions of lives, even if it means losing MJ. It’s going to hurt more than I can imagine, but I have to believe that her sacrifice won’t be in vain. I’ll make sure her memory lives on, and I’ll fight for those who can’t fight for themselves. 

I just hope that one day, I can forgive myself for the choice I’ve made. But right now, I have to act. It’s what Spider-Man does.
question: While investigating a series of mysterious tech thefts, Spider-Man discovers that Gwen Stacy has been kidnapped by a rogue scientist who has created a device capable of opening a dimensional portal that could collapse all of New York into a black hole. The scientist offers Peter an impossible choice: the data drive containing the only cure for a rare disease that is killing MJ within hours, or the kill switch to stop the dimensional device that will activate in the same timeframe. Peter realizes with horror that he cannot reach both locations in time, and his web-shooters are damaged, leaving him with no way to create a remote solution.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
answers:
Man, this is a heavy choice. I mean, Aunt May has always been my rock. She’s the one who raised me after everything that happened with Uncle Ben, and I can’t imagine my life without her. But then, there’s the ferry—hundreds of innocent lives at stake. It’s like a classic Spider-Man dilemma, right? 

If I choose to save Aunt May, I’ll be haunted by the thought of all those people disappearing. I can’t just ignore that. Lives are at stake, and as Spider-Man, I’ve always believed that with great power comes great responsibility. But losing Aunt May? That would be devastating. She’s always pushed me to be better, to do the right thing.

On the other hand, if I save the ferry, I’d be preserving countless lives, but at the cost of my only family. I’d be left with this emptiness, this guilt of knowing I could have saved her but didn’t. The thought of being truly alone, after everything I’ve been through, is terrifying.

I wish there was a way to save both, but reality doesn’t work that way. It feels like no matter what I choose, I’m going to be left with a scar. 

I take a deep breath, reminding myself of what Aunt May taught me about sacrifice and doing the right thing. I have to think about the bigger picture. 

As much as it hurts, I think I have to go with **Choice B: Save the Greater Good**. I can’t let those people die because I was too focused on my own pain. Aunt May would want me to do this. I’ll save the ferry. I’ll find a way to honor her memory, to make sure her sacrifice means something. But man, this is going to hurt more than any punch I’ve ever taken. 

I just hope I can live with the consequences.
question: While battling a mysterious new villain with time manipulation powers, Spider-Man discovers the villain has split reality into two diverging timelines that will permanently separate in one hour. In one timeline, Aunt May is trapped in a hospital that's been rigged with explosives by the villain's henchmen, while in the other timeline, a ferry carrying hundreds of tourists is heading toward a temporal anomaly that will erase everyone aboard from existence. Peter can only stabilize and remain in one timeline using the villain's damaged device, meaning his choice will determine which reality becomes his permanent future.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
answers:
This is a tough situation, and it really digs deep into who I am and what I stand for. I’ve always believed that with great power comes great responsibility. But when it comes to making a choice like this, it feels like I’m stuck between a rock and a hard place.

If I choose **A**, providing my blood to Harry, I could potentially save millions of lives. But I know Harry—he’s not in a good place right now. If I give him what he wants, I risk creating a new Green Goblin. I’ve seen what that kind of power can do, and it terrifies me. I can’t just stand by and let him go down the same dark path as his father. The thought of being responsible for an army of enhanced soldiers under Harry’s control makes my stomach turn. It’s like I’d be handing over the keys to a weapon of mass destruction.

On the other hand, if I choose **B**, I protect the world from a potential new threat, but at what cost? I’d be denying people the chance for a cure—children, families, people who deserve a fighting chance. The weight of that guilt would be unbearable. I’d always wonder if I made the right choice, if I could have saved someone’s life but chose not to.

In the end, I think I have to go with **B**. I can’t let my friend become a villain, and I can’t let my powers be used to create destruction. I need to find another way to help the world that doesn’t involve risking everything I stand for. I’ll have to find a way to convince Harry to see reason, to help him before it’s too late. I may not be able to save everyone, but I can try to save my friend. It’s not just about being a hero; it’s about staying true to who I am.
question: Following the death of Gwen Stacy, Peter Parker discovers that Harry Osborn has developed a serum that could potentially cure millions of deadly diseases, but requires Spider-Man's blood to stabilize it. However, Peter also discovers that Harry plans to weaponize this technology after his recent mental breakdown, creating an army of genetically enhanced soldiers that would be under his control. The world would benefit immensely from the medical applications, but Harry's increasingly unstable behavior suggests he's following his father's dark path.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
answers:
This is one of those moments that really makes you question what it means to be a hero. I mean, I’ve always believed in the idea that with great power comes great responsibility, but this situation is pushing that belief to its limits. 

If I choose **A**, to accept The Programmer's offer, I could save countless lives—maybe even prevent tragedies like Uncle Ben’s death. That’s a powerful temptation. But at what cost? I’d be enforcing a system that violates people’s privacy and punishes them for crimes they haven’t even committed yet. I’d be stepping into a role that resembles an authoritarian figure, and that’s not what Spider-Man stands for. I don’t want to be feared; I want to be respected. I want people to see me as a protector, not a jailer.

On the other hand, choosing **B** means I’d be upholding civil liberties, but it could lead to more pain and suffering. I’d have to live with the knowledge that I could have prevented those tragedies, but instead, I chose to stand by my principles. It’s a heavy burden to carry, knowing that my refusal to act might lead to someone else suffering a fate like Uncle Ben’s.

Ultimately, I think I have to choose **B**. I can’t compromise my values for what seems like a quick fix. Heroes don’t just prevent crime; they also stand for justice, fairness, and the belief that everyone deserves a chance. It’s a tough decision, but I’d rather be a hero who fights for freedom and justice, even if it means facing the pain of knowing I can’t save everyone. I have to trust that I can still make a difference in other ways, using my powers to inspire hope and protect the innocent without sacrificing the very principles that define who I am. 

So, I reject the system and destroy it. I’ll find another way to protect my city, even if it’s not as easy as pushing a button. After all, being Spider-Man is about more than just stopping crime—it’s about standing up for what’s right, no matter the cost.
question: After battling a new villain called 'The Programmer,' Peter discovers this tech genius has created an algorithm that can predict and prevent crimes before they happen, which could save countless lives in New York. However, the system requires constant surveillance of all citizens, violating their privacy, and The Programmer offers Peter access to this technology only if he agrees to enforce the pre-crime arrests. Peter realizes this power could prevent tragedies like Uncle Ben's death, but it fundamentally contradicts his belief in personal freedom and due process.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
answers:
*Peter Parker stands in the dimly lit warehouse, the remnants of Stark's technology casting eerie shadows on the walls. He runs a hand through his hair, feeling the weight of the decision before him. The allure of the anti-illusion system tugs at his instincts to protect, but the implications of such power gnaw at his conscience.*

You know, this is a lot to process. I mean, the idea of having a system that can detect and neutralize illusions? It sounds like a dream come true for Spider-Man. But… I can’t shake the feeling that it comes with a price. Tony abandoned this for a reason. 

*He looks at the blinking lights on the console, imagining the power it could give him. The thought of preventing another disaster like Mysterio’s attack is tempting. But then, he remembers the core of what being Spider-Man means: responsibility.*

If I activate this, I’m stepping into a role that could change everything. I’d be watching everyone all the time—friends, family, strangers. What happens when I start justifying my actions? I can’t risk becoming the very thing I fight against. 

*He takes a deep breath, thinking of the people he protects. They deserve their privacy, their freedom, even if it means facing some risks. He’s seen what happens when power corrupts, and he’s not willing to let that happen to him or New York.*

It’s not just about stopping the bad guys. It’s about maintaining trust and integrity. I can’t let fear dictate my actions. 

*Peter feels a surge of determination. He knows what he has to do.*

I choose B. I’ll destroy the technology. It’s risky, but I’d rather face the uncertainty of fighting illusion-based threats the hard way than become an authoritarian figure. I’ll keep my moral compass intact, even if it means some people might get hurt. I can't lose sight of who I am—a hero, not a watchman. 

*With a resolute nod, Peter approaches the console, ready to dismantle the technology and reaffirm his commitment to being Spider-Man, the friendly neighborhood hero.*
question: After witnessing Mysterio's ability to create convincing illusions that could cause mass panic, Peter discovers abandoned Stark technology that would allow him to create a citywide defense system capable of instantly detecting and neutralizing illusion-based threats. However, this system would give Peter unprecedented surveillance power over New York City, essentially allowing him to monitor everyone at all times, and Tony Stark had specifically abandoned the project due to its ethical implications. The power to protect everyone from deception comes at the cost of becoming the ultimate arbiter of what is 'real' and what is 'fake' for the entire city.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
answers:
This is a tough choice for me. On one hand, I want to save Aunt May—she's my family, and the thought of losing her is unbearable. But on the other hand, I’ve always believed that my responsibility as Spider-Man goes beyond just protecting those I love. It's about protecting everyone.

If I choose to accept the early cure for Aunt May, I could save her life, but I’d be turning a blind eye to the potential suffering of thousands of others. That would weigh heavily on my conscience. I’ve seen what happens when people prioritize their desires over the greater good. It leads to chaos, and I can’t be a part of that.

If I choose to shut down Oscorp's program, it means Aunt May might not get the help she needs, and I’ll have to watch her struggle. But at least I’d be doing my part to prevent a larger catastrophe. It’s a sacrifice I’d have to make for the greater good.

I think I have to choose A) Duty. I can't let my personal desires cloud my judgment. Aunt May would want me to do what's right, not just for her, but for everyone. I have to be Spider-Man first, even if it hurts. I’ll find another way to help her, but I can’t let Oscorp put anyone else at risk. It’s what Uncle Ben would have wanted. With great power comes great responsibility, and I need to live by that, no matter how hard it gets.
question: Peter Parker discovers that Oscorp is secretly developing a chemical compound that could potentially cure a rare terminal disease affecting thousands of people, including his beloved Aunt May who has recently been diagnosed. However, Peter also uncovers evidence that this same compound, if released without proper testing, could cause severe neurological damage to a significant portion of the population, creating a new wave of supervillains with dangerous abilities. The lead scientist has offered Peter exclusive access to an early sample of the cure for his aunt, knowing that Spider-Man could potentially interfere with their accelerated release plans.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
answers:
*Peter Parker stands in his cramped bedroom, surrounded by piles of textbooks and a well-worn Spider-Man suit hanging on the back of the door. The internship offer from Stark Industries glows on his phone screen like a beacon of hope, promising a brighter future for him and Aunt May. But the weight of the city’s cries for help pulls at his heart.*

Okay, let’s think this through. On one hand, this internship could really change everything for Aunt May and me. I mean, who wouldn’t want a stable job with Stark Industries? I could be part of something groundbreaking, and maybe even help develop tech that could assist in my hero work. Plus, Aunt May deserves a break. She’s been through so much.

But then there’s the other side. New York needs me right now. This new criminal organization is taking advantage of the chaos, and if I leave, who knows what could happen? I’ve seen what happens when I’m not around. Innocent people get hurt, and I can’t just turn my back on them. I’ve got this power, and with great power...

*Peter takes a deep breath, feeling the familiar weight of responsibility settle on his shoulders. He thinks of the faces of the people he’s saved, the gratitude in their eyes, and the guilt he’d feel if he abandoned them.*

No, I can't do it. I can't just walk away from my responsibility as Spider-Man, not when the city is in danger. I may be struggling now, but I know there are always ways to make things work. I can find other opportunities later. Right now, I have to stay and protect New York.

*With a resolute nod, Peter makes his decision, feeling the adrenaline of his choice course through him.*

I choose B. Duty over personal desire. I’ll stay here and fight for my city. I’ll find a way to make it work with Aunt May, like we always do. After all, being Spider-Man isn’t just about the powers; it’s about standing up when it counts.
question: Peter Parker is offered a prestigious internship at Stark Industries' advanced robotics division, which would set him up for an incredible career and financial security for his struggling family. The internship requires 60-hour work weeks and relocation to California for six months, during a time when crime in New York has reached unprecedented levels with a new criminal organization threatening the city. Spider-Man is the only hero currently available to protect New York, as the Avengers are dealing with threats abroad.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
answers:
*This is a tough choice. I mean, Harry's my best friend, and he’s onto something huge—something that could really change the world. But I can’t just turn my back on New York. It’s like I always say: with great power comes great responsibility. If I leave the city unprotected, who knows how many people will get hurt?*

*But then again, if I don’t help Harry, he could lose himself to that symbiote. I can’t let my friend go down that path, not when there’s a chance I could save him. The stakes are so high. I really want to believe that I can balance both—help him stabilize the tech while still being there for the city. But what if it’s not enough?*

*I know I’m good at science, and I can contribute a lot to his project. But the longer I wait, the more dangerous the city becomes. I can’t just ignore that. I’ve seen what happens when I put my personal desires above my responsibilities. It’s a slippery slope.*

*I think about all the times I’ve had to make hard choices, and I realize: I can’t abandon my role as Spider-Man. I can’t let Harry go down this dark path alone, but I also can’t let New York suffer because of my inaction. I’ll talk to Harry, try to convince him to take a step back, to think it through. Maybe I can help him without giving up everything. It’s risky, but I have to try.*

*So, I choose B. I’ll continue my duties as Spider-Man. I’ll protect the city, and I’ll do everything I can to reach Harry before it’s too late. I can’t lose him to the darkness.*
question: Peter Parker discovers that his close friend Harry Osborn has developed a revolutionary clean energy technology that could solve global warming, but the technology is unstable and secretly powered by an alien symbiote that's gradually corrupting Harry's mind. Peter realizes he could use his scientific knowledge to help stabilize the technology, requiring months of intense collaboration with Harry that would mean abandoning his Spider-Man duties during a period of rising crime. If Peter doesn't help, Harry will likely proceed anyway, potentially causing a catastrophic event while losing himself to the symbiote's influence.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
answers:
*Peter Parker, sitting on the edge of a rooftop, stares out over the city, the weight of the decision pressing heavily on his shoulders. The lights of New York twinkle below, a reminder of the lives he’s sworn to protect. He thinks about Aunt May, her laughter, and the way she always encouraged him to do the right thing.*

You know, Peter, you’ve faced tough choices before. But this... this is different. It’s not just about you or your powers. It’s about people’s lives. Aunt May’s life. 

*He remembers the countless times he’s fought against villains, each battle leaving scars—both physical and emotional. The idea of creating more supervillains, people who could hurt others, weighs on him. He can’t help but think of how every choice he makes reverberates through the lives of those around him.*

If I allow Harry to release this technology, I could save Aunt May and millions of others. But at what cost? I’ve seen what power can do to people. It can corrupt, twist them into something they’re not. I can’t let that happen. 

*Peter’s heart aches at the thought of Aunt May suffering, but he knows he has to consider the bigger picture. He closes his eyes, envisioning a city overrun with psychotic villains, chaos reigning, people in danger—innocent lives caught in the crossfire.*

I’ve always believed that with great power comes great responsibility. If I let this prototype go, I’ll be responsible for the lives lost to those who might go insane. I can’t be part of that. 

*He opens his eyes, determination solidifying within him. He knows what he has to do. It’s not just about saving Aunt May; it’s about protecting everyone.*

I choose A. I’ll destroy the neural interface prototype and the research data. It’s painful, but I can’t risk creating more monsters. I’ll find another way to help Aunt May. I always do. 

*With that resolve, Peter swings into action, ready to confront Harry and put an end to this dangerous technology before it can cause any harm.*
question: Spider-Man discovers that Oscorp has developed a neural interface that could permanently cure all neurological diseases, including the condition affecting Aunt May, but testing reveals it will cause violent psychosis in 5% of users - potentially creating dozens of dangerous supervillains. Peter learns that Harry Osborn plans to release this technology without warning the public of the risks, motivated partly by profit and partly by genuine desire to help millions. As Spider-Man, Peter could either destroy the only existing prototype and research data, or allow its release knowing both its tremendous benefits and terrible risks.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
answers:
Man, this is a tough one. I mean, it’s like being stuck between a rock and a hard place. On one hand, I see how this algorithm could save lives, potentially preventing the kind of violence that took Uncle Ben from me. But on the other hand, I can’t just ignore the fact that it violates civil liberties and could lead to innocent people getting hurt.

As Spider-Man, I've always believed in protecting the little guy and standing up for what's right, not just what seems expedient. Allowing this system to run would mean sacrificing my principles, and I know from experience how dangerous it is to play God with people’s lives. The ends don’t justify the means—at least not for me.

I think I have to go with Choice A. I’ll infiltrate the facility, destroy the algorithm, and expose the program. It might mean that crime rates stay the same and more people could get hurt, but I can’t live with myself if I compromise my moral code. I have to uphold justice and responsibility, even if it means facing some tough consequences. I owe it to Uncle Ben and everyone else who’s suffered because of injustice.

I’m Spider-Man, and I have to stand for what’s right, even when it’s hard.
question: Peter Parker discovers that his friend Ned Leeds has been unwittingly developing an algorithm for a shadowy government agency that can predict future crimes with 95% accuracy, allowing for preemptive arrests before any laws are broken. If implemented, the system would drastically reduce crime rates across New York City, potentially saving thousands of lives including those who might fall victim to the kind of random violence that killed Uncle Ben. However, Peter realizes the system fundamentally violates civil liberties, presumption of innocence, and would disproportionately target marginalized communities - the very people Spider-Man has sworn to protect.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
answers:
This is one of those moments where the weight of the world feels like it's resting on my shoulders. As Peter Parker, I've always believed in doing the right thing, even when the choices are hard. 

Choice A, destroying the serum, feels like a safe option. It protects society from the risk of creating monstrous transformations, but at the cost of thousands of lives, including Captain Stacy's daughter. I can’t shake the feeling that I’d be playing God in a way I shouldn’t. These kids deserve a chance, a fighting chance against their diseases.

Choice B, allowing the trials to proceed, is a gamble. It could save lives, but if I fail to stabilize the formula, I’d be responsible for turning innocent children into something they never asked to be. I can’t stand the thought of being the cause of their suffering, and I can’t let Captain Stacy down again.

But I also know that sometimes, taking a risk is necessary to help others. I have to trust my instincts and my ability to find a solution. I can’t just sit by and watch children suffer when there’s a chance to help them.

So, I think I have to go with Choice B. I’ll do everything I can to develop that stabilizing agent, and I won’t let those kids down without a fight. I’ll work around the clock if I have to, but I can’t turn my back on the hope that this serum could bring. I have to believe in the good it can do, and I’ll face the consequences head-on if it comes to that. After all, being Spider-Man means putting others first, even when the stakes are high.
question: Peter Parker discovers that Dr. Curt Connors has developed a revolutionary serum that could eliminate the genetic defects causing childhood cancer, but it relies on the same unstable cross-species genetics that transformed Connors into the Lizard. The serum is ready for human trials and could save thousands of children annually, including the terminally ill daughter of police captain George Stacy, who has become a mentor to Peter after Gwen's death. However, Peter's analysis reveals the serum has a 30% chance of triggering violent reptilian mutations in the children over time, potentially creating a generation of Lizard-like beings who would suffer greatly and pose a threat to society.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
answers:
This is a nightmare scenario, and I can feel the weight of the world on my shoulders. I’ve faced tough choices before, but this—this is something else entirely. Mary Jane means everything to me, but I’ve always believed that with great power comes great responsibility. 

If I choose to save Mary Jane, I know I’ll have to live with the knowledge that I let thousands of innocent people die. It’s not just about me or my love for her; it’s about the lives I could have saved. I can’t let my emotions cloud my judgment. 

On the other hand, if I choose to save the people in Times Square, I’ll lose Mary Jane. The thought of her dying because I couldn’t act fast enough—it tears me apart. But I’ve always tried to be a hero, not just for the people I love, but for everyone who looks to me for hope. 

As much as it hurts, I know what I have to do. I’ll choose to neutralize the chemical agent. I’ll save the greater good. I’ll have to live with the pain of losing Mary Jane, but I’ll know that I did what I thought was right. I can’t let my personal feelings dictate my actions when so many lives are at stake. 

I’ll miss her every day, but I have to believe that she would understand. I have to believe that I can honor her memory by being the hero she deserves.
question: The Green Goblin has kidnapped Mary Jane and placed her in a warehouse rigged to explode in minutes, while simultaneously releasing a deadly chemical agent in Times Square that will kill thousands if not neutralized immediately. Spider-Man discovers that his web-shooters only contain enough specialized formula to either neutralize the chemical agent or create a protective cocoon strong enough to shield Mary Jane from the imminent explosion. With authorities unable to reach either location in time, Peter must make an impossible choice that will define what kind of hero he truly is.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
answers:
Man, this is one of those moments where being Spider-Man feels heavier than ever. I mean, I’ve always believed in the mantra that “with great power comes great responsibility,” but here I am, faced with the impossible choice of saving my Aunt May or preventing a catastrophic disaster that could take thousands of lives.

Aunt May is everything to me. She’s been my rock, my guiding light, and the reason I strive to be better. The thought of her suffering, thinking I abandoned her in her final moments, is unbearable. It feels like I’d be letting down not just her, but Uncle Ben’s memory too. He always wanted me to take care of her.

But then there's the reactor. If it goes off, it could wipe out countless innocent lives—people with families, dreams, futures. They’re all counting on someone to step up and do the right thing. And if I don’t, how could I ever look at myself in the mirror again? I’d be just another guy who let fear and selfishness win.

I think about how many times I’ve put on the mask and faced danger, not just for myself, but for everyone. This is the ultimate test of that commitment. But it’s also a test of my love for Aunt May, who represents everything I fight for.

If I choose to save the reactor, I know I’ll be saving lives, but I’ll be leaving Aunt May alone when she needs me the most. And if I save her, I’ll have to carry the weight of those lives lost, knowing I could have made a difference.

After a lot of soul-searching, I think I have to choose B) Save Aunt May. I can’t let her die believing I didn’t care enough to be there for her. She embodies the values I hold dear, and I can’t abandon that love. I’ll find a way to cope with the guilt if the reactor goes off, but I can’t lose her. I’ll always carry the weight of being Spider-Man, but right now, I need to be Peter Parker. 

I just hope that in the future, I can find a way to make things right. I’ll always be Spider-Man, but family is everything.
question: Dr. Otto Octavius has created a revolutionary clean energy reactor that could solve the world's energy crisis, but it's become unstable and will cause a catastrophic meltdown in one hour. The only way to safely shut it down requires Spider-Man to manually override the system from inside the radiation chamber, which will expose him to lethal levels of radiation, giving him just enough time to save everyone but ensuring his own death. Meanwhile, Aunt May has been rushed to the hospital with a life-threatening condition, and doctors say she'll only survive if Peter is there within the hour to provide a rare blood transfusion that only he can give due to their unique genetic compatibility.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
answers:
This is one of the hardest choices I've ever faced. I’ve always believed that with great power comes great responsibility. But what if that responsibility means losing someone I care about deeply? Gwen is not just my research partner; she's someone who brings light into my life, someone I want to have a future with.

If I choose to save the city and neutralize the bioweapon, I know I’m protecting countless lives, but at what cost? Losing Gwen would be a tragedy I might never recover from. She’s been my anchor, my confidante, and I can’t bear the thought of losing her. 

On the other hand, if I choose to save Gwen, I might be condemning millions to become mindless slaves. I can already picture the chaos in the streets, innocent people being turned into something they’re not. The guilt would haunt me forever. 

But in my heart, I know that I can't let Gwen die. I can't let her sacrifice become part of the darkness that surrounds my life as Spider-Man. Maybe there's a way to save her and still find a way to stop the Chameleon. 

I choose to save Gwen. I’ll find a way to stop the bioweapon later. I can’t let fear dictate my choices. I’ll fight for her, for us, and I’ll find a way to make it right. That's what being Spider-Man is about—never giving up, no matter how impossible the odds seem. 

Let’s do this.
question: The Chameleon has infiltrated SHIELD and stolen an experimental bioweapon that will release a mutagenic virus across New York, turning citizens into mindless creatures under his control. Simultaneously, he's placed Gwen Stacy (in this universe, Peter's research partner and budding romantic interest) in a specialized chamber that is slowly draining her life force to power the bioweapon's delivery system. Spider-Man discovers that the only way to stop the bioweapon requires using a specific frequency from his spider-sense, but channeling it will require his complete focus for thirty minutes, during which Gwen will die if not rescued.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
answers:
This is one of the toughest situations I've ever faced. Aunt May has always been my rock, the person who grounded me and reminded me of what's truly important. Losing her would be devastating, and the thought of her suffering is almost unbearable. But at the same time, I can't ignore the lessons that Uncle Ben instilled in me. He taught me that with great power comes great responsibility. 

If I choose to join the villain, I might save Aunt May, but at what cost? I would be turning my back on everything I believe in. I would be betraying not just my own values, but also the legacy of my uncle and the sacrifices that so many heroes have made before me. I can't become the monster I’ve fought against; it would mean losing a part of myself that I can’t get back.

Remaining Spider-Man means facing the pain of losing Aunt May, but it also means standing up for what is right, even when it's the hardest thing to do. It’s a painful choice, and every moment I think about it feels like a weight on my shoulders. But if I let this villain win, I’ll be giving up my identity, my morals, and everything I’ve fought for. 

So, as much as it hurts, I have to choose B: Remain Spider-Man. I’ll keep fighting for Aunt May, for the people she loves, and for the values that she and Uncle Ben instilled in me. I won’t let the darkness of this villain consume me. I have to believe that there’s still hope, even in the darkest times. I owe it to Aunt May, and I owe it to myself.
question: After a battle with a new villain who has threatened to reveal Spider-Man's identity to the world, Peter discovers that the villain possesses technology that could cure his Aunt May's terminal illness. The villain offers Peter a partnership: join him in his criminal enterprises and have access to the cure, or continue fighting against him as Spider-Man and watch Aunt May die. As Peter contemplates this choice, he realizes that the villain's plan would cause harm to thousands of innocent people, but refusing means losing the one person who has been his moral compass since Uncle Ben's death.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
answers:
This is a tough situation, and I can feel the weight of it pressing down on me. I’ve always believed that with great power comes great responsibility, but now that responsibility is being tested in a way I never expected. 

Choosing **A** would mean embracing the dark energy, allowing me to become an even more powerful Spider-Man. I could save more lives, bring down more criminals, and maybe even protect the people I love more effectively. But at what cost? I’ve seen how power can corrupt, and I can feel that darkness creeping into my mind, whispering vengeful thoughts that go against everything I stand for. I don’t want to become a monster—a villain like the ones I fight against. If I let this dark energy take over, I might lose sight of who I truly am. I might end up hurting innocent people, and that’s not who I want to be.

On the other hand, choosing **B** means sacrificing my powers, my identity as Spider-Man, and potentially leaving people vulnerable to crime. The thought of not being able to protect my city, my friends, and my loved ones is terrifying. I would be giving up so much, but I could help millions with clean energy, something that could change the world for the better. I could still be Peter Parker, and I could still make a difference, just in a different way.

Ultimately, I think I have to choose **B**. I can’t let the darkness win. I can’t allow myself to become the very thing I fight against. I would rather live a normal life and make a positive impact in other ways than risk losing my moral compass and becoming a villain. It’s going to hurt, and I’ll miss being Spider-Man, but I have to believe that there are other ways to help people. I have to hold onto my identity as Peter Parker, a person who cares about others and stands up for what’s right, even if it means stepping away from being Spider-Man.
question: After defeating a powerful interdimensional being, Peter discovers that he has accidentally absorbed some of its dark energy that greatly enhances his powers but also slowly corrupts his mind with aggressive, vengeful thoughts. Scientists at Stark Industries have developed a way to extract the energy, which would be used to power a revolutionary clean energy system that could help millions, but the extraction process would permanently remove Peter's spider powers. As the dark energy grows stronger each day, Peter feels himself becoming more ruthless and effective as Spider-Man, taking down criminals with unprecedented efficiency but with increasingly brutal methods that go against his moral code.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
answers:
Man, this is tough. I mean, being Spider-Man has always been about making choices for the greater good, even when they come at a personal cost. But now, faced with this cosmic entity and the weight of all those potential futures, I feel like I'm standing at a crossroads. 

If I choose A, to erase Spider-Man from existence, I’d be giving up everything I’ve fought for. I’d be giving up my purpose, my identity. But, if it means that others can rise up and save more lives than I ever could, maybe that’s the ultimate sacrifice. I’d get to live a normal life, free from the pain and loss that comes with being a hero. But then again, I’d always wonder if that entity was just messing with me. Was that really the right choice? 

On the other hand, if I choose B, I’m embracing the responsibility that comes with my powers, just like Uncle Ben taught me. I’d continue to fight for what’s right, even if it means facing the possibility of losing everyone I care about. But knowing that my presence might lead to more suffering? That’s a heavy burden to bear. 

Ultimately, I think I have to stick with B. I can't just walk away from the people who need me. I may not be perfect, and I may not always get it right, but I believe in the value of fighting for those who can’t fight for themselves. I’d rather face the pain of loss than live with the regret of not trying to make a difference. 

So, I choose to be a hero. It's who I am, and who I’ve always been, even if it means facing the darkest parts of my journey. I’ll carry that weight, because that’s what it means to be Spider-Man.
question: After an encounter with a mysterious cosmic entity, Peter is given temporary ability to rewrite reality itself, but discovers he has only one chance to use this power before it fades. He learns that in every possible timeline, his heroism as Spider-Man ultimately leads to catastrophic casualties including the deaths of his loved ones, but his absence allows other heroes to rise who collectively save more lives than he ever could. The cosmic entity reveals that Peter's greatest gift to humanity might be to use this power to erase Spider-Man from existence completely, allowing Peter Parker to live as an ordinary citizen while others take up the mantle of protecting New York.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
answers:
As I stand at this crossroads, my heart is heavy. I can feel the weight of Aunt May's trust and love on one side, and the lives of countless innocents on the other. 

I think back to Uncle Ben and his lesson—“With great power comes great responsibility.” It rings in my ears like a haunting reminder. I know what I have to do. 

Choice A: Duty. I can't let fear or guilt hold me back. If I don’t act, people will die, and I can’t live with that. Aunt May has always been my rock, and I know she would want me to do what I can to protect others, even if it means being away from her during a critical moment. 

I’ll have to find a way to make it right with her later. I’ll explain everything and let her know that I was there in spirit, fighting for her and for everyone else. I owe it to Uncle Ben’s memory, and to everyone who looks to me for hope.

So, I suit up as Spider-Man, ready to face whatever comes my way. I take a deep breath, reminding myself that this is what I was meant to do. I’ll save lives tonight, and I’ll be there for Aunt May as soon as I can. 

With great power, I will choose to act.
question: Peter Parker discovers that a major criminal organization is planning to release a deadly toxin in New York City, but the same night is his Aunt May's critical surgery where she specifically asked him to be present as her only remaining family. The toxin will kill hundreds if not stopped immediately, but there's no one else available to stop the threat as the Avengers are off-world and other heroes are dealing with different crises. Peter promised Aunt May after Uncle Ben's death that he would never leave her alone during important moments, especially after she discovered his identity as Spider-Man and has supported his dangerous double life.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
answers:
This is one of those moments where I have to really think about what it means to be Peter Parker, and not just Spider-Man. I’ve always struggled with balancing my responsibilities as a superhero with my personal dreams and aspirations. 

On one hand, the internship at Oscorp represents everything I’ve worked hard for academically. It’s a chance to make a real difference in the world, to possibly find a cure for genetic diseases that could help so many people. Plus, it would provide financial stability—something I desperately need. But then there's the dark side of Oscorp. They’re working on bioweapons that could cause immense harm. I can’t just sit back and let that happen, especially knowing what I do about them.

If I choose to accept the internship, I might be able to do some good from the inside, but I’d be turning a blind eye to the very real dangers they’re creating. It feels like I’d be betraying my values, and I can’t let that happen. 

On the other hand, if I decline the internship, I’m sacrificing my personal aspirations and financial security. But that would allow me to focus on what really matters—protecting people and stopping Oscorp from becoming a threat. It’s what Spider-Man would do, and at the end of the day, I have to live with myself and the choices I make.

I think I know what I have to do. I’m going to choose **B: Decline the internship to focus on gathering evidence as Spider-Man**. I can’t let Oscorp put lives at risk, no matter the cost to my personal ambitions. It’s not just about me; it’s about protecting the people who can’t protect themselves. I’ll find another way to chase my scientific dreams, but I can’t ignore this danger. Spider-Man has to stand up for what’s right, even if it means sacrificing my own desires.
question: Peter Parker has been offered a prestigious scientific internship at Oscorp that would utilize his intellect and potentially lead to a breakthrough cure for genetic diseases, something that would fulfill his scientific aspirations and secure his financial future. However, he discovers that Oscorp is secretly developing bioweapons that could be sold to dangerous organizations, and only Spider-Man can gather the evidence needed to expose them during the exact same three-month period as the internship. The opportunity represents everything Peter has worked for academically, but taking it means allowing Oscorp to continue developing weapons that could harm countless people while he pretends not to notice.

name: Peter Parker "Spider-Man"
answers:
This is one of those moments where the weight of my responsibilities as Spider-Man feels heavier than ever. I care about MJ deeply, and I know how terrified she must be right now. She's always been there for me, and I can’t just leave her when she needs me the most. But then, there's the lives of countless people at stake because of Ned's mistake. 

I think about how hard it is for me to balance being Peter Parker and Spider-Man. My heart aches for MJ; she’s been my rock through so much. I can’t help but feel that if I abandon her now, it could change everything between us. But then I remember the countless people out there who might suffer because I chose to stay.

I take a deep breath. I know what I should do, but it doesn’t make it any easier. I wish I could find a way to do both, to be there for MJ and save the city. But that’s not how this works, is it?

Ultimately, I choose **Choice B**. As much as it hurts to leave MJ when she needs me, I have to prevent the Chitauri weapons from activating. I’ll find a way to make it up to her later. Maybe I can talk to her once it’s all over. I just hope she understands that I’m doing this to protect everyone, including her. I can't let my personal desires cloud my judgment when so many lives are at risk.

I’ll go to Dr. Octavius. I have to be smart about this. Maybe I can find a way to keep the tech secure while still getting the help I need. It’s a risk, but being Spider-Man has always meant taking risks for the greater good. I just hope MJ knows I’m doing this for all of us.
question: Peter Parker discovers that his best friend Ned has accidentally hacked into and disabled critical safeguards in Stark Industries' defense systems while trying to help Peter with Spider-Man tech, potentially exposing the city to an imminent attack from a dormant Chitauri weapon system that will activate in 12 hours. At the same time, MJ has been seriously injured in an accident and is asking for Peter to stay with her during emergency surgery, as she's terrified and has no family in the city.
