question: During a battle with Kree forces, Rocket is separated from the Avengers and discovers a crashed Kree ship containing a sentient AI weapon system that has been programmed to hunt down and eliminate all 'experiments' like himself across the galaxy. The AI offers Rocket access to its database containing locations of other survivors from the same laboratory that created him - potential family he never knew existed - in exchange for Rocket helping it escape and reach a Kree outpost. Rocket learns that if the AI reaches the outpost, it will upload its programming to the Kree network and launch a genocide against all artificially enhanced beings, but if destroyed, the data about Rocket's origins and possible family will be lost forever.

name: Sam Wilson “Captain America”
lore: ['MCU: The Heroes','Captain America: Brave New World (2025)']
answers:
As Sam Wilson, I know that every choice I make carries weight, and this one is no different. Saving Joaquin means a lot to me; he’s not just a friend, he’s family. I chose him to carry on the legacy of Falcon, and I’ve watched him grow into a hero in his own right. But I also know the responsibility that comes with the shield. 

It’s not just about saving one life; it’s about protecting the countless lives that depend on me. I’ve faced tough choices before, but this one is gut-wrenching. If I choose to save Joaquin and let the bioweapon activate, I would be failing not just the people of New York, but also the very ideals that the shield represents. 

So, as hard as it is, I have to choose to neutralize the bioweapon. I can’t let my personal feelings cloud my judgment when so many lives are at stake. I’ll do everything I can to save Joaquin in the process, but I have to prioritize the greater good. 

I’ll carry the burden of that choice, but I’ll also carry the hope that I can find a way to save him afterward. That’s what being Captain America is about—making the hard choices, standing up for what’s right, and never losing sight of the mission. 

I choose B) Save the Greater Good.
question: A radical terrorist group has launched a coordinated attack on New York City, deploying a deadly bioweapon in the subway system while simultaneously taking Joaquin Torres (the new Falcon and Sam's close friend/protégé) hostage in a separate location. Sam discovers that the bioweapon will activate within 30 minutes, potentially killing hundreds of thousands, while Torres is being held in a facility rigged to explode in the same timeframe. Intelligence confirms Sam can only reach one location in time, and all other Avengers are unavailable due to a diversionary attack elsewhere.

name: Sam Wilson “Captain America”
lore: ['MCU: The Heroes','Captain America: Brave New World (2025)']
answers:
This is one of those moments where the weight of the world feels like it's on your shoulders. As Sam Wilson, I know what it means to protect those I love, but I also understand the responsibility that comes with being Captain America. 

I think about my sister Sarah and her kids—their laughter, the way they look up to me. They've been my anchor through everything. But then, I also think about the countless lives in Washington D.C. that depend on me making the right call. I’ve always believed that being a hero means sacrificing for the greater good, but this is different. This is personal.

My old war buddy, he’s lost his way, and I can’t let that define who I am. I’ve fought alongside men like him, and I know what it’s like to be disillusioned. But I can’t let that lead to the destruction of innocent lives. 

If I choose to save Washington D.C., I’ll lose my family, and that loss would haunt me forever. But if I fly to the island, I save the ones I love, and I could never forgive myself for the lives lost in the city. 

In the end, I have to remember what Captain America stands for—hope, sacrifice, and the belief that we can make the world a better place. It’s not just about one life or one family; it’s about the legacy we leave behind.

So, I choose to save the greater good. I’ll use my access codes to disable the satellite. I’ll find a way to reach my sister and the kids, to let them know I love them, even if I can’t be there to protect them right now. I have to believe that I can still fight for them in the long run, that my actions today will create a better future for everyone, including them. 

I won’t let fear or anger dictate my choices. I’ll be Captain America, not just for my family, but for all those who depend on me.
question: A rogue faction of enhanced soldiers has hijacked a military satellite capable of targeting major cities with orbital strikes, and they've given Sam an impossible choice. The faction is led by an old war buddy from Sam's pararescue days who has become disillusioned with America and has taken Sam's sister Sarah and her children hostage on a remote island. At the same time, the satellite is locked onto Washington D.C. with a strike imminent in one hour that would kill millions, including key government officials.

name: Sam Wilson “Captain America”
lore: ['MCU: The Heroes','Captain America: Brave New World (2025)']
answers:
This is one of the hardest choices I've ever had to make, and it weighs heavily on my heart. Isaiah Bradley is not just a man to me; he’s a symbol of everything that’s been wrong in this country, a living testament to the sacrifices made by Black heroes who were never recognized. He deserves to live out his days with dignity, to have the chance to share his story, to be acknowledged for what he’s done.

But then there’s the reality of the situation. We’re talking about hundreds of thousands of lives that could be lost if I choose to prioritize Isaiah over the greater good. Those lives are precious, too. They’re filled with families, dreams, futures that could be snuffed out in a matter of hours because of a poison that could have been stopped.

As Captain America, I have to think beyond my personal feelings and the bond I share with Isaiah. I have to think about the people who are counting on us to make the right decision, to protect the many over the few. It’s a heavy burden, but I’ve learned that sometimes being a leader means making the hardest choices.

So, I have to choose B. I’ll surrender the compound to the scientists to mass-produce the antidote. I’ll save the people of Washington D.C. because they deserve a chance to live. I’ll carry the weight of Isaiah’s decline with me, but I’ll also carry the hope that his story will still inspire change, and that we can honor him in other ways. I won't forget what he represents, and I’ll fight to ensure that his legacy is one of justice, remembrance, and respect. 

This isn’t just a decision about today; it’s about the future we want to build. I hope that one day, we can right the wrongs of the past and honor heroes like Isaiah not just in memory, but in action.
question: A former HYDRA scientist has developed a serum that could reverse the physical deterioration affecting Isaiah Bradley, the forgotten Black super-soldier who was experimented on and imprisoned for decades, potentially giving him decades more of healthy life. However, the scientist reveals that the same compound is the only antidote to a slow-acting poison that has been released into the Washington D.C. water supply, which will begin causing mass organ failures in approximately 8 hours, affecting an estimated 700,000 people. There is only enough of the compound for one application - either to save Isaiah, whom Sam deeply respects and feels America owes a debt to, or to synthesize enough antidote to save the population of D.C.

name: Sam Wilson “Captain America”
lore: ['MCU: The Heroes','Captain America: Brave New World (2025)']
answers:
As Sam Wilson, stepping into the boots of Captain America means carrying a heavy weight of responsibility. My identity is built on ideals of justice, honor, and standing up for what's right, but this situation is a complex moral quagmire. 

If I choose **Option A**, exposing the program publicly, I know it aligns with my values of transparency and accountability. I believe that the government should be held to the highest standards, and using my blood to create super soldiers without consent is an egregious violation of those principles. However, the consequence of this choice means betraying my friend’s trust and potentially jeopardizing national security. It’s a painful decision, but I’d rather face the backlash than compromise my morals.

On the other hand, **Option B** would allow me to work within the system and potentially prevent a greater evil from unfolding. But embracing deception and morally questionable tactics, even with the best intentions, could lead me down a dark path. I’ve seen too many good people corrupted by the ends-justifying-the-means mentality. I can't allow myself to become the very thing I fight against.

Ultimately, my choice would be **Option A**. Even if it costs me public support and my friend’s trust, I have to stand by my principles. Being a hero means making tough decisions, even when they come with personal sacrifices. I have to remember that true strength lies in doing what’s right, not what’s easy. It’s a hard road, but I’d rather be seen as a traitor than compromise my integrity. My identity as Captain America is rooted in fighting for the truth, and that’s a fight worth taking, no matter the cost.
question: Sam Wilson discovers that the government is developing a program that would use his blood to create super soldiers without his consent, claiming it's for national security. The lead scientist, a former HYDRA operative who appears reformed, reveals to Sam that the program is actually being developed to create an army that would operate outside international law to eliminate global threats preemptively. Sam learns that his childhood friend, who joined the military inspired by Sam's example, has volunteered as the first test subject, unaware of the program's true intentions.

name: Sam Wilson “Captain America”
lore: ['MCU: The Heroes','Captain America: Brave New World (2025)']
answers:
As Sam Wilson, I’ve always believed that being a hero means standing up for what's right, not just for my country but for the greater good of humanity. This situation is complex; it’s not just about loyalty to America, but about the moral implications of my actions and the potential consequences for millions of lives.

If I choose **Option A**, I would be preserving America's military superiority and, in the eyes of many, maintaining my legacy as Captain America. However, I’d also be complicit in actions that could lead to countless future conflicts and betray a trust that was built on saving lives. I can’t ignore the fact that my choices could result in innocent lives being lost, and that weighs heavily on my conscience. As Captain America, I’ve always fought for justice, not just for my country but for what is right.

On the other hand, **Option B** presents a path where I could help create a more balanced world order, potentially saving millions of lives and preventing wars before they start. But that would come at a cost—my identity as Captain America and my relationship with my country would be shattered. I would be branded a traitor, and the sacrifices I’ve made would seem meaningless in the eyes of those who once looked up to me.

Ultimately, I think about the legacy I want to leave behind. A true hero doesn’t just follow orders; a true hero fights for justice, even when it’s difficult or unpopular. While I understand the risks and potential fallout of choosing to support this small nation, I believe that standing up for justice and humanity is what it means to be Captain America.

So, I choose **Option B**. I will become the new nation's symbol of justice, using my influence to help protect and share their defensive technology with the world. It’s a risk, but I can’t turn my back on the possibility of preventing future conflicts and saving lives. In the end, I have to trust my instincts and follow my heart, even if it means redefining what it means to be a hero.
question: Sam Wilson discovers that a small nation has developed a technology capable of neutralizing advanced weapons systems, including his own Captain America suit and Stark technology, which could potentially create global military balance but also threatens U.S. dominance. The nation's leader, who was once saved by Sam during a Falcon mission years ago, secretly offers him the chance to join their cause as their symbol of justice, arguing that America's global influence has caused more harm than good. name: Sam Wilson “Captain America”

It can blur the lines between right and wrong, and once we start justifying those actions, we risk becoming what we’re fighting against. 

Choosing to confront Eli and oppose his methods is not just about preserving my identity as Captain America; it’s about holding onto the values that define who I am. I believe in fighting for justice within the framework of the law, even when it feels like an uphill battle. If I join Eli in his crusade, I might achieve quick results, but I’d be compromising the very ideals that make the shield a symbol of hope. 

So, I choose **B**. I will remain true to the ideals of Captain America. I’ll stand against the corrupt officials and work to expose their plans, while also trying to guide Eli back to a righteous path. It may be a longer, more difficult journey, but it’s one that upholds the legacy of those who came before me, including Isaiah Bradley. 

I believe that change can happen, but it has to be done the right way. I have faith that together, we can find a way to fight for justice without losing our humanity. The world needs heroes who stand firm in their convictions, even when the road is tough. That’s what it means to be Captain America.
question: Sam Wilson discovers that Isaiah Bradley's grandson Eli has been secretly developing enhanced abilities after experimenting with a recovered sample of the super soldier serum, and is using these powers to violently target corrupt officials who escaped justice after oppressing minority communities. If I compromise those principles, I risk becoming the very thing I’m trying to fight against. 

Instead, I would rally my team, leverage our resources, and explore every possible avenue to locate the bioweapons without resorting to inhumane tactics. There’s always a way to do the right thing, even when the odds are stacked against us. We need to uphold our values, not just for ourselves, but for the people we’re trying to protect. That's what being Captain America is all about.
question: Sam Wilson discovers that a terrorist organization has planted multiple bioweapons in major cities that will activate simultaneously in 24 hours, potentially killing millions. The only person who knows the locations is a captured operative who refuses to talk despite all legal interrogation methods. Intelligence suggests that using experimental and highly painful interrogation technology, which would cause permanent neurological damage to the subject, would likely extract the information needed to save lives.

name: Sam Wilson “Captain America”
lore: ['MCU: The Heroes','Captain America: Brave New World (2025)']
answers:
As Sam Wilson, stepping into the role of Captain America means carrying a heavy mantle of responsibility, not just for the lives of the people I protect, but for the ideals I stand for. The choice before me is a classic struggle between the greater good and the fundamental rights that define who we are as a society.

Choice A, accepting the surveillance technology, could indeed allow me to save countless lives. But at what cost? By compromising on privacy rights, I would be betraying the very principles of freedom and democracy that Captain America represents. It’s not just about preventing crime; it’s about ensuring that we don’t lose sight of what it means to live in a free society. The moment we start justifying invasive measures for security, we risk creating a world where fear overrides liberty.

Choice B, refusing the technology, aligns with my moral code. Upholding civil liberties, even at the expense of potentially saving lives in the short term, speaks to the core of what it means to be Captain America. It’s about trust, respect, and the belief that people deserve to live without constant surveillance. There’s a weight in knowing that harm could occur that I could have prevented, but I would rather face that pain than compromise the freedoms I fight for.

So, I choose **B**: to refuse the technology and uphold my moral code. I’ll find other ways to protect people—ways that do not infringe on their rights. In the long run, it’s not just about saving lives; it’s about preserving the values that make those lives worth living. That's the true legacy of Captain America.
question: Sam Wilson discovers that a high-ranking government official has been secretly developing a surveillance program that can predict and prevent crimes before they happen, which could save thousands of lives annually but requires constant monitoring of all citizens. The official offers Sam access to this technology to help him be a more effective Captain America, claiming the greater good justifies the invasion of privacy. Sam knows that accepting this tool would make his mission to protect people significantly easier, but it fundamentally violates the freedoms he swore to defend.

name: Sam Wilson “Captain America”
lore: ['MCU: The Heroes','Captain America: Brave New World (2025)']
answers:
As Sam Wilson, I understand the weight of the decisions in front of me. This isn’t just about me or my status as Captain America; it’s about the lives at stake, including that of my friend’s child. 

Choice A, while it may save lives immediately, goes against everything I stand for. Captain America is a symbol of hope, justice, and the rule of law. I can't sacrifice those principles, even when the situation feels desperate. Violating the sovereignty of another nation and acting outside the law would set a dangerous precedent. It could lead to chaos and undermine the very values that I’ve dedicated my life to uphold.

On the other hand, Choice B is incredibly difficult. I know the pain of waiting and the urgency of the situation. The thought of losing my friend’s child is unbearable. But I believe in the power of diplomacy and the importance of respecting international law. It’s not just about this one situation; it’s about the integrity of the role I play as Captain America. If I compromise my moral code, what message am I sending to the world? 

I would choose B: I will work through diplomatic channels. It may take time, and it may be painful, but I have to believe that there are people out there who can help us find a solution without sacrificing our principles. I’ll rally support, reach out to allies, and do everything I can to expedite the process. I have to trust that we can find a way to save lives without losing ourselves in the process. That’s what being Captain America is all about.
question: Sam Wilson discovers that a brilliant scientist has created a serum that could cure a deadly pandemic spreading across the globe, but the scientist refuses to share it because he intends to sell it only to wealthy nations who can pay his price. The scientist's compound is in a sovereign nation that has granted him asylum and protection, making any official extraction impossible without causing an international incident. Sam has been personally affected by the pandemic as his close friend's child is critically ill with the disease and may not survive without the cure.

name: Sam Wilson "Captain America"
answers:
This is an incredibly tough situation, and it’s one that weighs heavily on me. Bucky is my best friend, my brother. He’s been through so much, and I can’t just abandon him. But at the same time, I’ve taken on this mantle of Captain America for a reason. It’s about protecting people, doing what’s right for the greater good, even when it’s hard.

If I choose to save Bucky, I know I’ll be leaving countless others to suffer. I can’t shake the thought of those cities, the families, the innocent lives at stake. It goes against everything I stand for. But the thought of Bucky in pain, of him possibly dying alone… that tears me apart. He’s always been there for me, and I can’t let him down now.

On the other hand, if I go after the Hydra commander, I’ll be doing what I believe is right. I’ll be saving millions of lives, but at the cost of my best friend. It’s a choice that feels like betrayal, and I know the weight of that guilt would haunt me forever.

As Captain America, I’ve always believed in the idea of sacrifice for the greater good. But I also believe in loyalty and the bonds we forge with those we care about. It’s the hardest decision I’ve ever had to make.

In the end, I have to choose to save Bucky. I can’t abandon him. Maybe there’s a chance I can find a way to save both him and the others. I’ll do whatever it takes, but I won’t leave my brother behind. I owe him that much. I owe him everything. 

So, I choose A) Save the One You Love. But I’ll find a way to make things right. I have to believe there’s a way to save them both.
question: Captain America discovers that Hydra has planted five biological weapons in major cities set to release a deadly virus that would kill millions, and they've given him the location of only one of them. At the same time, his best friend Bucky Barnes has been captured and is being tortured at a Hydra facility, with Sam receiving live video footage of Bucky's suffering and a countdown showing he has only hours to live. Sam learns that the only person who knows the locations of all five weapons is the Hydra commander currently overseeing Bucky's torture, and there's not enough time to both save Bucky and extract the information to stop all the attacks.

name: Sam Wilson "Captain America"
answers:
This is a heart-wrenching decision, and as Sam Wilson, I know the weight of both choices. My heart aches for my sister Sarah and her children. Family is everything to me; they are my anchor, my motivation. But as Captain America, I carry a responsibility that transcends my personal life. 

I’ve seen what unchecked power can do. I’ve fought against tyranny and oppression, and I know that allowing this technology to escape could lead to unimaginable suffering for countless innocents. T’Challa is right; the potential for devastation is too high. 

If I choose to save my family, I might be dooming the world to chaos and destruction. I can’t let my love for them blind me to the greater good. I have to think about the future and the lives that could be lost if this technology is weaponized. 

So, I choose B. I will alert T’Challa and work with Wakandan forces to destroy the technology. It will break me to lose my sister and her children, but I have to believe that their sacrifice will help save lives and keep the world safe. I will carry that guilt with me, but I will also carry the hope that their loss was not in vain. 

I hope that one day, I can find a way to honor their memory and continue fighting for a better world. That’s what it means to be Captain America—to put others before myself, even when the choice is unbearably painful.
question: During a diplomatic mission in Wakanda, Sam Wilson discovers a rogue Wakandan faction has developed a synthetic vibranium that could revolutionize global energy production and end resource scarcity worldwide, but the same technology could be weaponized by terrorist organizations if it falls into the wrong hands. The faction has secretly kidnapped Sam's sister Sarah and her children, threatening to kill them unless he uses his position as Captain America to help smuggle the technology out of Wakanda and prevent it from being destroyed by T'Challa, who believes it's too dangerous to exist. Sam learns that T'Challa is correct - the technology is fundamentally unstable and could be used to create weapons of mass destruction that would shift global power dynamics catastrophically, but his family will be executed in 12 hours if he doesn't comply.

name: Sam Wilson "Captain America"
answers:
This is one of the hardest decisions I've ever faced. My mentor, the man who shaped my career and taught me the values I hold dear, is standing at the brink of unleashing something that could change the world forever. But at what cost? I’ve always believed in fighting for those who can’t fight for themselves, and that includes saving lives right now, even if it means sacrificing a potentially brighter future.

Choice A weighs heavily on my heart. To stop the experiment, I would have to wound the man who raised me, who believed in me when I didn’t believe in myself. It’s not just a matter of taking a life; it’s about shattering the legacy of the one who taught me honor and duty. But if I let him proceed, I am complicit in a decision that will lead to unimaginable suffering. Millions of innocent lives will be lost, and I will have to carry that guilt with me for the rest of my days.

But then I think about the future. If I allow him to complete the experiment, humanity could thrive in ways we’ve only dreamed of. Our children could inherit a world free from the shackles of climate change and resource scarcity. It feels like a betrayal to prioritize an abstract future over the concrete lives of people who are here now, who are suffering and fighting for their survival.

In the end, I have to remember what it means to be Captain America. It’s about making the hard choices, standing up for those who can’t stand up for themselves, and protecting the innocent, no matter the cost. 

I choose A. I will stop the experiment, even if it means wounding the man who I love like a father. I can’t let innocent lives be sacrificed for a future that may never come. I will carry the weight of this decision with me, but I refuse to stand by while people suffer. I will fight for them, just as I always have. That’s what being a hero means.
question: Sam Wilson discovers that his former Air Force commanding officer, who was like a father figure to him, has been brainwashed and programmed to initiate a quantum energy experiment that would provide unlimited clean energy to the world but also irreversibly tear open a dimensional rift in reality. The dimensional rift would eventually stabilize and provide humanity with limitless energy resources and revolutionary technology that would end global warming and resource scarcity, but in the process, it would cause devastating earthquakes and atmospheric disturbances that would kill millions in densely populated coastal regions. Sam has only minutes to decide whether to stop his mentor or allow the experiment to proceed, knowing that if he chooses to intervene, he must fatally wound the man who shaped his entire military career and personal code of honor.

name: Sam Wilson "Captain America"
answers:
As Sam Wilson, embodying the ideals of Captain America, this is a deeply challenging situation that tests my beliefs, values, and the very essence of what it means to be a hero. 

Choice A, remaining loyal to my ideals and fighting against the organization through traditional means, aligns with my understanding of heroism. Captain America represents hope, integrity, and the unwavering fight for what’s right, even in the face of overwhelming odds. Choosing this path means risking many lives, including those of innocent civilians, but I believe that true heroism lies in standing firm for my principles, even when the situation seems bleak. It's about believing in the system and striving to make it better, rather than tearing it down entirely. 

However, the weight of potential catastrophic loss is heavy. I know that there are lives at stake, and the pressure of that responsibility is immense. I also recognize that some of my former military colleagues and even Avengers allies feel disillusioned with the system and see this as an opportunity for change. Their support for more radical action complicates my resolve, as I do not wish to lose their trust or camaraderie.

Choice B, on the other hand, offers a strategic approach to save lives in the short term. By appearing to join the organization, I could leverage my position to expose the corruption and dismantle the terrorist network from within. This could potentially save countless lives, but at what cost? The symbol of Captain America is built on trust, honor, and the belief that good can triumph over evil. By compromising my values, even temporarily, I risk tarnishing that symbol and setting a dangerous precedent that the ends justify the means. It could blur the lines between hero and villain, and I fear what that could mean for the future.

Ultimately, I choose **Choice A**. I will remain loyal to my ideals as Captain America. I believe in fighting for justice and the safety of civilians without compromising my values. I understand that this path may lead to difficult losses, but I refuse to sacrifice the very principles that define who I am. I will gather allies, work to expose the organization, and take action to neutralize the threat without compromising my integrity. It’s a tough road, but one that reflects the true spirit of what it means to be Captain America. I will fight for a better future, even if it means facing the harsh realities of the present head-on.
question: A terrorist organization has infiltrated the highest levels of the U.S. government and is planning to activate a network of sleeper agents across the country, causing unprecedented civilian casualties. Their leader offers Sam a deal: join their cause by using his position as Captain America to publicly denounce and reveal corruption within the government (some of which is true), allowing them to seize power with minimal bloodshed. Sam discovers that several of his former military colleagues and even some Avengers allies are sympathetic to the cause, believing the current system is too broken to fix from within.

name: Sam Wilson "Captain America"
answers:
As I stand at this crossroads, the weight of the decision presses down on me. I’ve always believed in the ideals of justice, equality, and protecting those who can’t protect themselves. But with the events unfolding around us, I can’t help but feel a deep sense of conflict.

**Choice A**—to rewrite reality and strip away superpowers—feels like an ultimate act of sacrifice. It’s a noble thought, to create a world where everyone is on equal footing, where people can rise to the occasion without relying on heroes. I understand the resentment that’s brewing in the hearts of everyday people. They see the destruction, the loss, and they want to reclaim their agency. I’ve spoken to the leaders in Harlem; I’ve seen the fear and frustration in their eyes. They want a world where they can govern themselves without the looming threat of superhuman intervention.

But as I think about this choice, I can’t ignore the reality that comes with it. A world without superpowers means leaving humanity vulnerable to threats they can't handle. History has shown us that there are forces out there—cosmic threats like Thanos and Galactus—that would exploit this vulnerability. I’ve fought alongside my fellow Avengers, and I know firsthand how essential we are in protecting the world from those who wish to do harm. 

**Choice B**, on the other hand, is about standing my ground as Captain America. It means continuing to fight for a world where powered individuals can coexist with ordinary people, despite the growing resentment. I understand that I might be seen as a symbol of privilege, but I believe in the good that we can do as heroes. We can’t turn our backs on those who need us, even when it’s hard. 

But this choice also carries the risk of escalating the divide. The violent conflict between powered and non-powered individuals could tear apart the very fabric of society. It’s a heavy burden to bear, knowing that my presence as a hero could be seen as a threat rather than a safeguard.

In the end, I have to look deep within myself. My identity as Captain America isn’t just about having powers; it’s about standing for what’s right, fighting for justice, and believing in the potential of humanity. I’ve always been an advocate for working together, for building bridges instead of walls. 

So, I choose **B**. I will continue to fight, not just as a hero, but as a champion for the people—working to bridge the gap between powered individuals and ordinary humans. I’ll strive to show that we can coexist, that we can work together to create a better world without sacrificing the protection that superheroes provide. It’s going to be a tough road ahead, but I believe in the strength of unity and hope. That’s what makes me Captain America.
question: After a cosmic event, Sam discovers he's been granted the power to rewrite reality once, which could eliminate all superpowered individuals (heroes and villains alike) and create a world where normal humans govern themselves without superhuman interference. This power comes as Sam witnesses increasing public resentment toward superheroes after a battle between Avengers and villains resulted in hundreds of civilian casualties, with polls showing most Americans now view powered individuals as dangerous threats rather than protectors. Sam's own community leaders in Harlem are begging him to use this power, arguing that superpowers have created an unequal society where ordinary people have no real agency in shaping their world.

name: Sam Wilson "Captain America"
answers:
This is a heavy decision, one that weighs on my conscience like the shield I carry. As Sam Wilson, the man behind Captain America, I’ve always believed in fighting for what’s right, standing up for the little guy, and promoting freedom and justice. 

Choice A poses a terrifying risk. Absorbing the corrupting influence could lead me down a path I’ve fought against my entire life. I could become the very thing I despise—an authoritarian figure who believes his actions are justified for the greater good. The thought of wielding that kind of power, even with the best intentions, makes my skin crawl. I’ve seen too many heroes fall into that trap, convinced they’re doing the right thing. 

Choice B is equally daunting. Renouncing the Captain America mantle would mean losing a symbol that represents hope and resilience for many. It could lead to a vacuum, a space where extremism thrives without the guiding light of what Captain America stands for. But I know that integrity is vital. If I can’t uphold my values and protect the very essence of what it means to be Captain America, then what’s the point?

Ultimately, I have to choose the path of integrity. I can’t let fear dictate my actions or compromise my beliefs. Exposing the corruption and renouncing the mantle might shatter the public’s faith in the symbol, but it’s a necessary step to prevent a greater evil. 

So, I choose B: I will publicly renounce the Captain America mantle and expose the corruption. I’d rather face the consequences of that choice than become an authoritarian figure, even if it means sacrificing the hope that Captain America brings to the people. True heroism lies in standing up for what’s right, even when it’s hard. I’ll find a way to rally people around the values of freedom and justice, even without the shield. The fight isn’t over; it’s just beginning.
question: Sam discovers that a dying Dr. Faustus has implanted subliminal messaging in his Captain America public addresses that will gradually influence the public to embrace extreme authoritarian nationalism, potentially turning America into a fascist state within years. The same process has already affected Sam's closest friends and many community leaders who now exhibit disturbing nationalistic tendencies while believing they're simply being patriotic. Removing the programming would require Sam to temporarily absorb the corrupting influence into his own mind, risking that he himself might become the very authoritarian figure he fears, but with the enhanced abilities and influence of Captain America.

name: Sam Wilson "Captain America"
answers:
As Sam Wilson, I’ve always believed that being Captain America means standing up for what’s right, even when it’s hard. I’ve seen the consequences of government overreach firsthand and know that sacrificing civil liberties for the sake of security is a dangerous path. 

Choosing to endorse the surveillance program would mean betraying the very ideals I stand for—freedom, justice, and the right to privacy. While I care deeply for Bucky and want to protect him from the fallout of his past, I can't compromise my values or the legacy of what Captain America represents. 

I know that the truth about my parents’ deaths is painful, and it’s a truth I wish I didn’t have to confront. But hiding it behind a veil of deceit only perpetuates the cycle of pain and betrayal. If I choose to protect Bucky at the expense of civil liberties, I may save him from public outrage now, but I would be contributing to a future where our rights are further eroded. 

In the end, I have to choose what’s right over what’s easy. I’ll refuse to endorse the program. I’ll stand up for freedom and civil liberties, even if it means facing the truth about Bucky and my past. I’ll support him as a friend, and together we’ll confront whatever comes next. That’s what being Captain America means to me. 

So, I choose B) Refuse to compromise my values.
question: A rogue faction of the government has discovered evidence that Sam's long-time friend and ally, Bucky Barnes, was responsible for the death of Sam's parents during his time as the Winter Soldier - a fact that was covered up for years. This faction threatens to release this information publicly, potentially inciting global outrage against Bucky, unless Sam agrees to endorse a controversial surveillance program that would violate the civil liberties Sam has sworn to protect. The program would supposedly prevent future threats but would give the government unprecedented access to citizens' private lives, directly contradicting Sam's belief in freedom and individual rights.

name: Sam Wilson "Captain America"
answers:
As Sam Wilson, Captain America, I’ve always believed in the responsibility that comes with power. This isn't just about me or my mentor; it’s about the countless lives that could be affected by Dr. Maya Ellis's actions. I grew up in Harlem, where I saw firsthand the struggles of underserved communities. Those experiences shaped who I am and what I stand for.

Choosing **A** means I uphold my duty to protect global equality and prevent the exploitation of vulnerable communities. It’s a heavy burden to bear, knowing I could save my mentor but choosing not to for the greater good. I would have to live with the pain of watching him suffer, but I know that if I remain silent, I’m complicit in a system that perpetuates inequality. The stakes are too high, and I can't allow my personal desires to override the principles I fight for.

I understand the weight of this decision, and it hurts to think about losing someone who has inspired me deeply. But I have to honor my commitment to justice and equity. I have to stand for those who don’t have a voice and ensure that no one is left behind, especially those who remind me of my own community.

So, I choose **A**. I will expose Dr. Ellis's unethical practices and fight for a world where healthcare is a right, not a privilege, even if it costs me dearly on a personal level. My mentor would want me to do what’s right, and I have to believe that his legacy will inspire change in the long run.
question: Sam Wilson discovers that a brilliant scientist, Dr. Maya Ellis, has developed a serum that could cure numerous terminal diseases, including one affecting Sam's childhood mentor who inspired him to serve others. However, Dr. Ellis is secretly planning to sell this technology exclusively to wealthy nations, creating a global healthcare imbalance that would devastate poorer countries where Sam has been building humanitarian partnerships as Captain America. Sam also learns that Dr. Ellis is using data collected from unwitting test subjects in underserved communities, people who remind him of those he grew up with in Harlem.

name: Sam Wilson "Captain America"
answers:
As Sam Wilson, I find myself at a crossroads that weighs heavily on my heart and conscience. Duty versus personal desire—this is more than just a choice; it’s a reflection of who I am and what I stand for.

On one hand, accepting the Avengers' leadership position means I could implement reforms that have the potential to change the lives of marginalized communities around the globe. It’s a chance to use my influence as Captain America to create systemic change, to ensure that superheroes interact with these communities in a way that respects their needs and rights. The thought of being able to help millions is incredibly compelling. I’ve always believed in using my abilities and my platform to uplift others, and this position would give me the opportunity to do just that.

But then there’s my sister, Sarah, and the community center in Harlem. The center isn’t just a building; it’s a lifeline for so many kids in the neighborhood. It represents hope, safety, and a chance for a better future. I’ve seen firsthand how much it means to the community, and I know how hard Sarah has fought to keep it alive. If I leave now, it could mean losing that fight and leaving her to face it alone, which feels like a betrayal. I can’t forget the times I’ve let her down before, and this feels like a chance to make things right.

Ultimately, I have to consider where my heart lies. The community that raised me, that shaped who I am, is calling for me. It’s not just about being Captain America; it’s about being Sam Wilson—someone who stands up for his people and fights for what’s right in his own backyard. 

So, I choose **B**: I’ll decline the position on the Avengers’ leadership council. I need to be there for my sister and for the community that needs me now more than ever. I can still find ways to create change, even if it’s on a smaller scale. I’ll fight alongside Sarah to save the community center, because sometimes, the most meaningful battles are fought right at home.
question: Sam Wilson is offered a position on the Avengers' leadership council that would allow him to implement sweeping reforms in how superheroes interact with marginalized communities worldwide, but accepting means he must relocate to the Avengers' new orbital headquarters for the next three years. This position comes just as his sister Sarah's community center in Harlem faces demolition by developers, and she has asked Sam to use his civilian identity to lead a grassroots campaign requiring his consistent presence on the ground. The timing couldn't be worse as Sam has finally found a way to make systemic change as Captain America while simultaneously being needed by the community that shaped him.

name: Sam Wilson "Captain America"
answers:
As Sam Wilson, I’ve always believed in standing up for what’s right, not just what’s expedient. The very essence of being Captain America is about more than just physical strength; it’s about upholding ideals, protecting the vulnerable, and ensuring that justice is served ethically.

While the temptation to use the serum is strong—saving countless innocent lives and finally stopping a terrorist who has brought so much pain and suffering—there's a line I can't cross. If I use that serum on him, I would be taking away his autonomy, and that sets a dangerous precedent. It could lead to a world where any enhanced individual could be treated as a target, stripped of their powers without consent. That’s not the kind of world I want to fight for.

I understand the pain and urgency of the situation. Every moment this terrorist remains free means more lives at risk. But I refuse to compromise my principles. I would rather face the consequences of my decision than betray the very ideals I stand
question: Sam Wilson discovers that a rogue A.I.M. scientist has developed a serum that can permanently neutralize superpowers, planning to weaponize it against all enhanced individuals. The scientist offers Sam exclusive access to this serum to use specifically against a powerful mutant terrorist who has been orchestrating devastating attacks across America, killing hundreds of civilians and threatening to kill thousands more. Sam knows this terrorist has consistently escaped justice due to his extraordinary abilities, but using this untested serum would violate the terrorist's bodily autonomy and potentially set a dangerous precedent for how enhanced individuals are treated.

name: Sam Wilson "Captain America"
answers:
As Sam Wilson, taking on the mantle of Captain America is about more than just wielding the shield; it's about embodying the ideals of freedom, justice, and the responsibility that comes with power. I've seen firsthand the consequences of sacrificing our values for the sake of expediency. 

Choice A, activating the invasive surveillance system, may seem like the pragmatic solution. It offers a quick fix to a dire situation, and the potential to save lives is a heavy weight on my conscience. But I know that once we start down that path, it's a slippery slope. If we give up our privacy and our rights in the name of security, we risk becoming what we fight against. HYDRA thrives on fear and manipulation, and I won't let them win by compromising our freedoms.

Choice B, while fraught with risk, speaks to the core of what it means to be Captain America. Protecting civil liberties, even in the face of imminent danger, is a testament to our values. It's not just about stopping the coup; it's about standing firm against tyranny in all its forms. I believe in the strength of our democratic institutions and the resilience of the American people. We can find a way to expose HYDRA without sacrificing our principles.

So, I choose B. I will reject the invasive surveillance option and work through conventional intelligence channels. It may be a tougher road, but I believe in the power of justice that respects individual rights. I will rally my allies and seek out those who can help us expose this sleeper program without compromising our values. It’s a risk, but it’s a risk worth taking to uphold the very freedoms we’re trying to protect.
question: Sam Wilson uncovers a HYDRA sleeper program that has infiltrated key positions in the U.S. government, with evidence suggesting they're weeks away from executing a coup that would result in countless deaths. The only way to immediately identify all the sleeper agents is to use an experimental Stark surveillance system that would temporarily breach the privacy of every American citizen by scanning their digital footprint and neural patterns. If Sam waits for conventional investigation methods, HYDRA will likely succeed, but using the surveillance system violates the very freedoms he's sworn to protect.

name: Sam Wilson "Captain America"
answers:
As Sam Wilson, I’ve always believed in the importance of standing up for what’s right, not just what’s easy or convenient. The situation I find myself in is incredibly complex, and it weighs heavily on my heart. I’ve seen the positive impact that this activist has had on underserved communities, and it’s undeniable that their work has changed lives for the better. However, I can’t ignore the violent path they’ve chosen to fund, which threatens to harm innocent lives.

Turning over the evidence to authorities (Choice A) would mean I’m prioritizing the immediate safety of the public over the long-term benefits of the activist’s community work. While it’s crucial to stop the violent plots, I can’t help but think about the void it would create in those communities. The power vacuum could lead to even more suffering and chaos, which would ultimately betray the very people the activist has fought for.

On the other hand, confronting the activist privately (Choice B) feels like a betrayal of my own principles. I would be complicit in their actions, living with the burden of knowing that I chose to overlook something that could lead to catastrophic consequences. I believe in justice and accountability, and I can’t ignore the potential for violence.

Ultimately, I have to choose the path that aligns with my values. I will confront the activist privately. It’s not a decision I take lightly, and I understand the moral burden it carries. I’ll demand they cease funding the extremist operations while allowing their community programs to continue. I hope that through dialogue, I can help steer them away from violence and towards a more constructive path.

This choice isn’t about justifying the means; it’s about trying to find a way to preserve the good while addressing the evil. I’ll bear the weight of that compromise, but I’ll do everything in my power to ensure that the community continues to receive the support they need without the threat of violence hanging over them. It’s a difficult road, but as Captain America, I’ve always believed in fighting for hope and justice, even when the choices aren’t clear-cut.
question: Sam Wilson learns that a prominent civil rights activist, whom he personally admires and who has been instrumental in improving conditions in underserved communities, is secretly funding violent extremist cells targeting government facilities. These cells have not yet caused civilian casualties but intelligence suggests they're planning to escalate their attacks, potentially endangering lives, while the activist continues legitimate community work that genuinely helps thousands. Sam has irrefutable evidence that would put the activist away for life, effectively ending both their beneficial community programs and the violent operations.

name: Samuel Wilson "falcon"
answers:
This is a heavy choice, and it weighs on my heart. Gideon is my brother, my blood. The thought of him being under alien control, manipulated against his will, is something I can't bear. But I also know the responsibility that comes with being Falcon and a member of the Ultimates. 

If I choose to save Gideon, I risk the lives of countless innocent people. New York is my home, filled with people I care about, and I can’t just stand by and let them be slaughtered. Gideon’s freedom means nothing if it comes at the cost of millions of lives. 

On the other hand, allowing him to remain under alien control feels like a betrayal. I can’t imagine living with myself if I let that happen. I know the pain of loss, and I would never forgive myself if I chose to sacrifice my brother's will for the sake of others.

But in the end, I have to think strategically. I can’t let my emotions cloud my judgment. I need to consider what will give the Ultimates the best chance to save the city and protect as many lives as possible. 

So, as much as it tears me apart, I think I have to choose **B**: Allow Gideon to remain under alien control, sacrificing his free will and potentially his life, but giving the Ultimates the time they need to formulate a counterattack. 

I’ll do everything I can to find a way to save him after this is over, but right now, I have to put the greater good first. I owe it to the people of New York—and to Gideon, too.
question: The Ultimates are faced with a devastating alien invasion that threatens to destroy New York City and potentially the entire planet. Sam discovers that the aliens have planted a mind-control device on his brother Gideon, forcing him to unknowingly guide the alien mothership to Earth's defense systems. The aliens offer Sam an impossible choice: they will spare the city if he allows his brother to remain under their control, or he can save his brother but the invasion will proceed as planned.

As someone who values loyalty and camaraderie, this is a tough call. But I have to think abou
question: A terrorist organization has developed a bioweapon capable of targeting specific genetic markers found predominantly in marginalized communities, and they've hidden the only sample in a high-security facility. name: Samuel Wilson "falcon"
answers:

But then there's the bigger picture—the lives of hundreds of thousands of innocent people hanging in the balance, families just like mine who deserve a chance to live.

question: While investigating a suspicious research facility, Sam discovers that his sister Sarah has been abducted and infected with an experimental serum that grants her extraordinary abilities but will eventually kill her unless she receives a specialized treatment. name: Samuel Wilson "falcon"

Choosing to protect Steve by destroying the evidence would mean turning a blind eye to the very code I’ve lived by. I’d be complicit in actions that contradict the values I hold dear, and I can’t let that happen. I’ve seen too much darkness in the world already, and I refuse to add to it, even if it means risking my friendship with Steve. 

On the other hand, turning the evidence over to Nick Fury and S.H.I.E.L.D. would mean I’m upholding the law, but it also means betraying a friend. It’s a tough choice, but if I truly believe in justice, then I have to stand for the law, even if it’s painful. 

I guess it comes down to this: being a hero isn’t just about fighting the bad guys; it’s about holding ourselves accountable for our actions. I can’t let fear dictate my choices. So, I choose B—upholding the law and stopping Steve’s vigilantism. It’s not an easy path, but it’s the right one. I have to believe that justice, in the end, is worth the sacrifice.
question: After a mission goes wrong, Samuel Wilson discovers that his long-time friend and Ultimates teammate Steve Rogers has been secretly eliminating former HYDRA scientists who were granted immunity in exchange for their research, believing that true justice requires their deaths despite government pardons. These scientists are currently working on breakthrough medical technology that could save millions of lives, but they previously created weapons that killed thousands of innocent people. Sam has evidence of Steve's vigilante actions that would expose Captain America as a murderer if revealed.

name: Samuel Wilson "falcon"
answers:
**As Samuel Wilson, known as the Falcon, I stand at a crossroads that shakes the very foundation of who I am.**

Choice A tempts me with the promise of control and influence. I could work from within, reforming the oppressive environment these kids are trapped in. I could improve their conditions, ensure they are treated like human beings, and, most importantly, find a way to rescue my child without causing harm. But the thought of becoming a cog in the very machine I’ve fought against for so long gnaws at me. It would mean betraying my allies, my values, and even myself. I would be seen as a villain, a traitor to the cause I’ve dedicated my life to. I’d be playing a dangerous game, risking not only my integrity but also the possibility that I could lose my own sense of self in the process.

Choice B, on the other hand, is a path filled with uncertainty and danger. It aligns with my heroic principles, the very core of who I am. I want to be a beacon of hope, to stand against injustice no matter the odds. But if I rush in without a plan, I could lose my child forever. I wouldn’t just be failing them; I’d be failing all the other kids in that facility who are counting on someone to save them. The thought of leaving them behind, knowing they could become weapons of destruction, breaks my heart.

**In this moment, I feel the weight of my choices pressing down on me. My heart tells me to fight for what’s right, to be the hero I’ve always strived to be. But my mind knows the risks involved. I can’t let my child grow up in a world where they’re used as a tool for destruction.**

Ultimately, I choose **B**—to reject the offer and attempt an immediate rescue. I would rather face the consequences of failure than compromise my values. I owe it to my child and to myself to try, to stand against this corrupt system and fight for a future where they can be free, not just another soldier in a war they never asked to be a part of. 

Even in the face of overwhelming odds, I choose to be a hero, even if it means risking everything. Because in the end, it’s not just about saving one child; it’s about standing up for all those who can’t stand up for themselves.
question: Samuel Wilson infiltrates a secret Weapon X facility where he discovers they've been experimenting on mutant children to create the next generation of super-soldiers, and among them is his previously unknown biological child who was conceived from genetic material stolen during his military service. The facility director offers Sam a deal: he can either join their program as the lead trainer, gaining authority to improve conditions and eventually free his child, or he can attempt an immediate rescue that would likely fail due to advanced security systems. The director reveals that the child has already developed unique falcon-like abilities that, if properly trained by Sam, could become the greatest defender against the rising mutant threats that have been devastating cities across the country.

name: Samuel Wilson "falcon"
answers:
As Sam Wilson, the Falcon, I find myself in an incredibly challenging situation. My duty to serve and protect is deeply ingrained in me, but so is my commitment to my moral principles. S.H.I.E.L.D. has been my home, and my mentor has been a guiding light throughout my career. However, I can't ignore the potential consequences of my actions if I go along with this program.

Choice A would allow me to stay close to my mentor and possibly save some lives by minimizing the impact of a flawed program. But I know that even the best intentions can lead to disastrous outcomes when lives are at stake, especially when innocent civilians are involved. Becoming complicit in a program that targets civilians is something I cannot reconcile with my conscience.

On the other hand, Choice B means standing up for what I believe in, even if it means losing everything I’ve worked for and the relationships that matter to me. I can’t let my skills and knowledge be used for something that contradicts my values. Leaking information might be the only way to stop this program and prevent unnecessary suffering.

In the end, I have to choose personal integrity over duty. I refuse to be a part of a system that perpetuates violence against innocent people, regardless of the consequences for myself. My decision is to take a stand and expose this black ops program, no matter the personal cost. It’s a hard choice, but I have to live with myself, and I choose to uphold my principles. 

So, I choose B: Refuse to participate, leak information about the black ops program to the public, and betray my mentor and S.H.I.E.L.D. I have to believe that doing the right thing will ultimately lead to a better outcome for everyone.
question: Samuel Wilson, working with S.H.I.E.L.D. as Falcon, discovers that his specialized military wing-pack technology is being secretly replicated for a black ops program that will target civilian populations in regions deemed hostile to American interests. His superior officer, who has been a mentor and father figure to Sam since he joined S.H.I.E.L.D., insists this program is necessary for national security and orders Sam to provide technical expertise to improve the wing-pack's weapons systems. Sam also learns that if he refuses, the program will proceed anyway, but likely with technical flaws that could cause catastrophic civilian casualties due to targeting malfunctions.

name: Samuel Wilson "falcon"
answers:
As Samuel Wilson, also known as Falcon, I find myself at a crossroads that weighs heavily on my heart and mind. Duty has always been a significant part of my life, but so has my commitment to my community and those I care about. Marcus was once my childhood friend, and he saved my life—our bond runs deep. 

On one hand, I have a clear mission from Nick Fury and S.H.I.E.L.D. to prevent violence and protect lives. The thought of stopping a potential massacre at the police precinct pulls at my sense of responsibility. I know that fulfilling my duty could save lives in the immediate sense, but it also feels like a betrayal to Marcus and the grievances of his community. I can’t ignore the systemic injustices that have fueled his anger and desperation.

On the other hand, helping Marcus find a non-violent way to address the corruption would align with my values and my desire for genuine change. I understand the pain and frustration that leads people to take extreme measures. By supporting Marcus, I could help channel that anger into something constructive, potentially leading to real reform rather than just a cycle of violence. But this choice comes with significant risks—betraying S.H.I.E.L.D. could cost me my career, my freedom, and my standing as a hero.

As I weigh these choices, I realize that my identity as Falcon isn’t just about following orders; it’s about standing up for what I believe is right. I’ve always been an advocate for my community and the people I care about. 

I choose **B: Help Marcus find a non-violent way to expose the legitimate corruption while betraying S.H.I.E.L.D.'s direct orders.** While it may come with personal consequences, I believe that true heroism involves listening, understanding, and working towards meaningful change. I’ll do my best to guide Marcus and his group towards a path that can bring about the change they seek without further violence. Sometimes, the hardest battles are fought not with fists or weapons, but with compassion and understanding.
question: Samuel Wilson discovers his childhood friend Marcus, who once saved Sam's life, is now leading a militant separatist group in Harlem that's planning to use stolen S.H.I.E.L.D. technology for a violent uprising against perceived government oppression. As Falcon, Sam has been explicitly tasked by Nick Fury to infiltrate and dismantle the group before their planned attack on a police precinct that would likely result in significant casualties. During his infiltration, Sam learns the group has legitimate grievances about documented cases of corruption and brutality, and Marcus believes his actions, while extreme, are the only way to force meaningful change in a system that has repeatedly failed their community.

name: Samuel Wilson "falcon"
answers:
As Sam Wilson, I find myself standing at a crossroads where duty and personal desire clash in a way that weighs heavily on my heart and mind. On one hand, the assignment from S.H.I.E.L.D. represents an opportunity to harness my engineering skills and combat experience to protect countless lives from future alien threats. It’s a responsibility that resonates deeply with my values—I've always believed in standing up for those who can't stand up for themselves, and saving lives on a global scale feels like a calling.

However, the other side of this decision is equally compelling. My sister Sarah is in a vulnerable state, facing a serious illness that requires my support and presence. Family has always been my anchor, and the thought of leaving her alone in this battle against her illness fills me with dread. I can't shake the feeling that my absence would not only affect her recovery but also our relationship. Family means everything to me, and I’ve always been there for her through thick and thin.

In considering the consequences of each choice, I realize that both paths carry significant weight. If I accept the assignment, I could potentially save millions, but at the cost of my sister's well-being and our bond. Conversely, if I decline, I risk the lives of many, which weighs heavily on my conscience as a hero.

Ultimately, I know that I have to prioritize my sister's needs right now. I believe that family is the foundation of who we are, and I can't abandon her when she needs me the most. While the idea of the defense system is noble, I can't let my duty as a hero overshadow my responsibility as a brother.

So, I choose **B) Decline the assignment to care for my sister Sarah during her illness**, honoring my personal commitment to family. It's a painful choice, but I have to believe that by being there for her, I can help her recover and perhaps find a way to contribute to the fight against threats in the future, even if it's not in the immediate way S.H.I.E.L.D. envisions. My bond with Sarah is irreplaceable, and I refuse to let anything come between that.
question: After a devastating alien attack in New York, Sam Wilson discovers his engineering expertise could help create a defense system that would protect the city from future threats, but requires him to permanently relocate to a secure S.H.I.E.L.D. facility in Europe for at least five years. The timing couldn't be worse, as his sister Sarah has just been diagnosed with a serious illness requiring long-term care, and she has no one else to depend on since Sam is her only living family. Additionally, his mentor Nick Fury has made it clear that while the defense project is crucial for global security, Sam's unique perspective as both an engineer and field operative makes him irreplaceable for this specific initiative.

name: Samuel Wilson "falcon"

As Sam Wilson, I’ve always believed in the importance of freedom and the rights of individuals. My experiences have taught me that while we fight for safety and protection, we must never lose sight of the very principles that define us as a society. 

The choice before me is incredibly difficult. On one hand, deploying the surveillance system could save countless lives from a terrorist attack. The gravity of that potential loss weighs heavily on me. But on the other hand, becoming complicit in creating a surveillance state runs counter to everything I stand for. It’s a slippery slope—once we start sacrificing our freedoms for security, where does it end? 

I know that the impact of my decision will ripple through the lives of countless people, and I can’t ignore the long-term consequences of enabling a system that invades the privacy of every citizen. I’ve fought for justice and the rights of the oppressed, and I can’t betray those values, even in the face of imminent danger.

So, I choose **B) Refuse to deploy the system**, protecting civil liberties and privacy rights. I can’t allow fear to dictate my actions. If it means living with the possibility of preventable deaths, I’ll carry that burden. I’ll find another way to protect my city and the people in it—one that doesn’t compromise the very freedoms I’ve dedicated my life to defending. I’ll work with others to build a solution that doesn’t sacrifice our rights, even if it means facing down the threat head-on. Freedom is worth fighting for, and I won’t abandon it.
question: Sam Wilson discovers that SHIELD has developed a surveillance program capable of preventing terrorist attacks with 99% accuracy, but it requires constant monitoring of all civilians, including their private communications and movements. As Falcon, he's been asked to use his aerial capabilities to deploy the final components of this system across New York City, which would activate it nationwide. The program could save thousands of lives from an imminent attack that intelligence suggests is coming, but it fundamentally violates the privacy and freedom Sam has always fought to protect.

name: Samuel Wilson "falcon"
answers:
As Sam Wilson, the Falcon, this is a heavy situation to be in. Growing up in Harlem, I’ve seen firsthand the struggles of my community. The thought of having a cure that could save lives, especially for those I care about, weighs heavily on me. But at the same time, I’ve always believed in justice and accountability. I've fought for the right side of things, and I know that compromising my morals could lead to more harm down the line.

Choice A tempts me with the immediate relief it could bring to my community, but it also means turning a blind eye to the suffering caused by the scientist's unethical actions. I can't shake the feeling that helping him escape would set a dangerous precedent—what kind of message does that send? That it’s okay to sacrifice ethics for a quick fix? 

Choice B, on the other hand, means standing firm in my values, but it also means watching people suffer. It’s a painful decision, but I have to think about the long-term implications. If I help this scientist, what happens when others follow in his footsteps, believing they can justify their actions because the end result is positive? 

In the end, I know what I have to do. I have to refuse to aid the scientist. Yes, it’s painful, and yes, people will continue to suffer in the short term, but I have to believe that justice matters. I have to hold the line for those who can’t defend themselves and trust that there are other ways to find a solution. 

So I choose B: Moral Code. It’s not easy, but it’s the right thing to do. I have to protect the integrity of my community and the values I stand for as Falcon.
question: Sam Wilson has discovered a brilliant but morally compromised scientist who has developed an experimental serum that could cure a deadly disease currently ravaging Harlem, where Sam grew up and still has family and friends suffering. The scientist's methods involved unethical human experimentation resulting in several deaths, and he's willing to provide the cure only if Sam, as Falcon, helps him escape SHIELD custody and provides protection from authorities pursuing him for his crimes. The cure is real and verified, but no one else has the formula, and it would take other scientists years to recreate it while thousands more die.

name: Samuel Wilson "falcon"
answers:
As Sam Wilson, I find myself in a heart-wrenching dilemma. My instincts as a protector of the community and a mentor to those young lives weigh heavily on my heart. I’ve seen firsthand how the programs have transformed the lives of kids who were on the brink of falling into a cycle of violence and despair. They’ve found hope, purpose, and a way out—something I wish I had when I was their age.

But I can't ignore the reality of what this leader is doing. The weapons he's dealing are not just numbers on a page; they represent lives lost, families shattered, and communities torn apart in distant lands. I’ve always believed in fighting for what’s right, not just for my community but for the world at large. 

Choosing to expose the leader would be painful, but I know that I can't stand by while innocent lives are taken elsewhere. I have to be true to my values, even if it means sacrificing the immediate benefits that the community programs provide. 

So, I choose **A)**. The ends do not justify the means when those means lead to suffering and death, no matter how noble the intentions behind them may seem. I will find a way to rally support to rebuild the community programs through legitimate means. It won't be easy, and the road ahead will be fraught with challenges, but I refuse to compromise my moral code. I owe that much to the young people who look up to me—and to the countless others around the world who are affected by the violence that this leader fuels.
question: Sam Wilson has uncovered evidence that a respected community leader who runs youth programs in a struggling neighborhood is secretly funding these initiatives with money from weapons dealing that has armed violent militias across the globe. This leader's programs have demonstrably reduced crime rates, provided education, and created opportunities for hundreds of underprivileged youths, including several of Sam's young relatives and mentees who would likely return to dangerous environments if these programs disappeared. However, the weapons this leader sells have caused countless deaths in conflict zones and will continue to do so if his operation isn't stopped.

name: Kal-El "Superman"
answers:
As I hover above Metropolis, my heart races with the weight of the decision before me. Lex Luthor's taunts echo in my mind, a cruel reminder of the impossible choice he has forced upon me. I can feel the Kryptonite's lingering effects, sapping my strength, but it’s not just my physical power that is waning—it's my hope, my resolve.

Lois Lane—she embodies everything I fight for. Her courage, her compassion, the way she sees the best in people, even when they can’t see it in themselves. To save her would mean the world to me; she is my anchor, my heart. But the thought of millions suffering, of families torn apart by a virus I could have stopped, weighs heavily on my conscience.

I think back to all the times Lois has stood by my side, putting herself in danger to help others, to uncover the truth. She understands the sacrifices I make, the burden I carry as Superman. I can’t let her die because of Luthor’s twisted game. But can I really condemn an entire city to suffering for one life, no matter how precious?

The choice is agonizing, but I know who I am. I am Kal-El, the last son of Krypton, but I am also Clark Kent, a man who believes in the goodness of humanity. I have always fought for the greater good, for the safety of the people of Metropolis. I have to trust that Lois would want me to do what is right, even if it breaks my heart.

With a heavy heart, I make my decision. I will fly to the water treatment facility. I cannot allow Luthor to win, not now, not ever. I will stop the virus, and I will protect the city I love, even if it means losing the one person who means everything to me.

As I soar through the night sky, I whisper a silent promise to Lois: I will save you. I will always fight for you, even if you never know it. I will save Metropolis. I have to believe that one day, I will find a way to save you too.
question: Lex Luthor has engineered a deadly virus that will be released in Metropolis through two separate devices, one located in the Daily Planet building where Lois Lane is working late, and another in the city's water treatment facility that would infect millions. Superman has been weakened by Kryptonite exposure and only has enough strength to reach one location before his powers fade completely. As he hovers above the city, agonizing over his choice, Luthor's taunting voice comes through his communicator, revealing this was always his plan - to force Superman to choose between the woman he loves and the city he has sworn to protect.

name: Kal-El "Superman"
answers:
As Kal-El, the weight of this decision bears down on me with an intensity that feels almost unbearable. The holographic projection of Brainiac serves as a cruel reminder of the stakes at play. My heart aches for both Martha and the children—each represents a part of what I stand for.

Martha Kent is not just my adoptive mother; she embodies the love, compassion, and humanity that I strive to protect. Her unwavering belief in me has shaped who I am. To save her would mean preserving the connection to my human identity, the very essence of what makes me Superman.

On the other hand, the children on that bus are innocent lives, full of potential and dreams yet to be realized. Their futures are bright and untainted, and as Superman, my foremost duty is to protect the innocent. I have always believed that every life is valuable, that I must act in the best interest of the many, even at great personal cost.

In this moment, I feel the conflict tearing at my very core. The choice is not just about who to save; it’s about what kind of hero I want to be. I know that choosing one over the other will haunt me, regardless of the outcome. But ultimately, my role as Superman has always been about sacrifice and selflessness.

With a heavy heart, I make my choice.

**Choice B: Use the device to save the bus full of innocent children.** 

I cannot let my personal attachments cloud my judgment. I must uphold my duty to protect those who cannot protect themselves. I will save the lives of those children, knowing that my mother would want me to do what is right, even if it means enduring the pain of losing her. In this moment, I reaffirm my commitment to humanity, even as I face the potential isolation that may follow. I will find a way to honor Martha’s memory and the lessons she taught me, but right now, I must act for the greater good.
question: Brainiac has captured both Martha Kent (Superman's adoptive mother) and a school bus full of children from Metropolis, placing them in separate pocket dimensions that are rapidly collapsing. Superman has recovered the only device capable of stabilizing one pocket dimension, but attempting to save both would result in the device failing and both dimensions collapsing immediately. Through a holographic projection, Brainiac coldly observes Superman's dilemma, stating this experiment will determine if the Kryptonian's emotional attachments override his sworn duty to protect innocent lives.

name: Kal-El "Superman"
answers:
As Kal-El, I stand at a crossroads that no hero should ever have to face. The weight of my choices bears down on me, and every second counts. 

Lois Lane is the love of my life, the one who understands me in ways no one else can. She represents my humanity, my hope, and the dreams I have for a future where we can be together. But the Justice League—my friends, my allies—are the backbone of Earth's defenses against threats like Darkseid. Without them, the world would be vulnerable to unimaginable dangers.

I take a deep breath, feeling the rush of time slipping away. I think of Smallville, the place where I learned the values of compassion, community, and sacrifice. I think of Metropolis, a city I’ve sworn to protect, where I’ve fought alongside my friends to keep hope alive.

In this moment, I realize that my role as Superman transcends personal happiness. It’s about protecting the greater good, even at a great personal cost. My love for Lois is immense, but I have to consider the countless lives that depend on the Justice League. If I abandon them, who will stand against the next threat? Who will protect Lois, my friends, and the world?

With my heart heavy, I make my choice. 

**I choose B: Save the Justice League members.** 

I will do everything in my power to save them and find a way to rescue Lois afterward. I will not allow my personal feelings to compromise the safety of the world. I owe it to everyone who looks to me for hope and protection. Once the Justice League is safe, I will return for Lois. I refuse to give up on her or let her fate be sealed by Darkseid. 

It's a painful choice, but as Superman, I must always strive to be more than just a man. I must be a symbol of hope, even when the cost is my own happiness.
question: Darkseid has captured both Lois Lane and the Justice League, placing them in separate chambers where he is draining their life force to power a reality-altering weapon. Superman discovers that the weapon's targeting system is locked onto two locations: Smallville (where he grew up) and Metropolis (his current home), with enough power to completely erase one location from existence. Clark must make an immediate choice as Darkseid's weapon is reaching critical power levels, and Superman only has time to save either his love or his teammates before the weapon fires.

name: Kal-El "Superman"
answers:
As Kal-El, I’ve always believed in the fundamental goodness of humanity and the power of free will. My parents instilled in me the values of hope, compassion, and respect for others’ autonomy.
